text: Preface
label: BODY

text: The Office of Security and Safety Performance Assurance (SSA) is responsible for the development,
label: BODY

text: promulgation, and evaluation of security programs, and the independent oversight of security; cyber
label: BODY

text: security; emergency management; and environment, safety, and health programs throughout the
label: BODY

text: Department.  SSA develops and assists in the implementation of strategies, policies, and technology
label: BODY

text: pertaining to the protection of national security and other critical assets entrusted to the Department; and
label: BODY

text: provides information and analysis regarding the effectiveness, vulnerabilities, and trends of the
label: BODY

text: Department’s security, safety, and other programs and functions of interest to departmental senior
label: BODY

text: management and other stakeholders. SSA also provides administrative support to the Office of the
label: BODY

text: Departmental Representative to the Defense Nuclear Facilities Safety Board.
label: BODY

text: Within the Other Defense Activities appropriation, the SSA program has three subprograms: Nuclear
label: BODY

text: Safeguards and Security (NSS), Security Investigations (SI), and Program Direction.  Within NSS are 3
label: BODY

text: key activities: Operational Support; Technology Development and Systems Deployment; and
label: BODY

text: Classification, Declassification, and Controlled Information.  Within SI are 3 key activities: Federal
label: BODY

text: Bureau of Investigation, Office of Personnel Management, and Related Security Investigations
label: BODY

text: Activities.
label: BODY

text: This Overview will describe Strategic Context, Mission, and Benefits.  These items together put the
label: BODY

text: appropriation in perspective.  The Annual Performance Results and Targets, Means and Strategies, and
label: BODY

text: Validation and Verification sections address how the goals will be achieved and how performance will
label: BODY

text: be measured.  Finally, this Overview will address Significant Program Shifts.
label: BODY

text: a  Reflects a 1% rescission in accordance with P.L. 109-148, Emergency Supplemental Appropriations to Address Hurricanes
label: BODY

text: in the Gulf of Mexico and Pandemic Influenza, 2006.
label: BODY

text: b  FY 2005 funding includes $14,608,000 for the support of the DOE Emergency Operations Center.  Funding was transferred
label: BODY

text: to the National Nuclear Safety Administration in FY 2006.
label: BODY

text: Overview
label: H4

text: FY 2007 Congressional Budget
label: BODY

text: Strategic Context
label: BODY

text: Following publication of the Administration’s National Energy Policy, the Department developed a
label: BODY

text: Strategic Plan that defines its mission, four strategic goals for accomplishing that mission, and seven
label: BODY

text: general goals to support the strategic goals.  As stated in the Departmental Strategic Plan, DOE’s
label: BODY

text: Strategic and General Goals will be accomplished not only through the efforts of the major program
label: BODY

text: offices in the Department but with additional effort from offices which support the programs in carrying
label: BODY

text: out the mission.  SSA performs critical functions, which directly support the mission of the Department.
label: BODY

text: These functions include developing and promulgating security policies, training, and technology
label: BODY

text: throughout DOE; assisting the United States and other governments track the use and movement of
label: BODY

text: nuclear material; and providing information to the Secretary and other DOE managers regarding the
label: BODY

text: status and effectiveness of the Department’s security and safety program implementation.
label: BODY

text: Mission
label: BODY

text: SSA provides for the development, promulgation, and evaluation of security programs, and the
label: BODY

text: independent oversight of security; cyber security; emergency management; and environment, safety, and
label: BODY

text: health programs throughout the Department; and provides security-related services to DOE
label: BODY

text: Headquarters.  SSA also provides administrative support to the Departmental Representative to the
label: BODY

text: Defense Nuclear Facilities Safety Board.
label: BODY

text: As stated in the Departmental Strategic Plan, DOE’s Strategic and General Goals will be accomplished
label: BODY

text: not only through the efforts of the major program offices in the Department but with additional effort
label: BODY

text: from offices which support the programs in carrying out the mission.  SSA performs critical functions
label: BODY

text: that directly support the mission of the Department.  These functions include:
label: BODY

text:  developing and promulgating clear and consistent security strategies and policies governing the
label: BODY

text: protection of national security and other critical assets entrusted to the Department;
label: BODY

text:  developing and providing standardized, comprehensive security, and safety training throughout the
label: BODY

text: Department;
label: BODY

text:  managing the Department’s protective force for DOE facilities in the National Capital Area,
label: BODY

text: including DOE’s Continuity of Government facilities and plans;
label: BODY

text:  providing executive protective services for the Department;
label: BODY

text:  managing the development and deployment of security technologies;
label: BODY

text:  developing and implementing Department-wide nuclear and radiological materials tracking and
label: BODY

text: accounting programs;
label: BODY

text:  assisting other governmental and departmental organizations in the mission of accounting for and
label: BODY

text: assuring the security of nuclear material throughout the world;
label: BODY

text:  managing the Department’s security investigations budget and personnel security programs
label: BODY

text: associated with providing access authorizations to DOE Federal and contract personnel;
label: BODY

text:  managing the U.S. Government-wide program to classify and declassify nuclear weapons-related
label: BODY

text: technology and implementing the requirements of Executive Order 12958 regarding the
label: BODY

text: classification and declassification of information that is vital to national security;
label: BODY

text: Page 14
label: BODY

text: Other Defense Activities/
label: BODY

text: Security and Safety Performance Assurance/
label: BODY

text: Overview
label: H4

text: FY 2007 Congressional Budget
label: BODY

text:  assisting Departmental and other U.S. Governmental organizations in providing adequate protection
label: BODY

text: to national security assets;
label: BODY

text:  providing specialized security support services to the Department associated with the development
label: BODY

text: and dissemination of security awareness information; maintenance of various security-related data
label: BODY

text: base systems; management of the foreign ownership, control, or influence and foreign visits,
label: BODY

text: assignments, and travel programs; and conduct of vulnerability assessments in support of the
label: BODY

text: implementation of the Design Basis Threat Policy;
label: BODY

text:  conducting performance appraisals to verify that the Department’s security interests are protected;
label: BODY

text: the Department can effectively respond to emergencies; and site workers, the public, and the
label: BODY

text: environment are protected from hazardous operations and materials; and,
label: BODY

text:  providing support for centralized leadership in resolving Defense Nuclear Facilities Safety Board
label: BODY

text: issues.
label: BODY

text: Benefits
label: BODY

text: DOE must implement effective security programs in an increasingly challenging threat environment.
label: BODY

text: The primary focus of SSA is on effectively and efficiently implementing protection programs that fully
label: BODY

text: respond to the evolving Design Basis Threat Policy by addressing programmatic and technical
label: BODY

text: uncertainties and establishing cooperation and useful dialog between managers and security
label: BODY

text: professionals at all levels.  Towards this end, and in support of the unprecedented security initiatives
label: BODY

text: announced by the Secretary in May 2004, SSA is: 1) streamlining existing security policies to remove
label: BODY

text: ambiguity in roles, responsibilities, and requirements; eliminate conflicts; and incorporate recent
label: BODY

text: updates; 2) emphasizing the deployment of innovative security technology to transition from manpower
label: BODY

text: intensive  to engineered systems that provide greater security at reduced lifecycle costs; 3) advancing the
label: BODY

text: professional development of DOE security and safety personnel to ensure that their training is
label: BODY

text: responsive to the needs of the DOE community; 4) increasing the capabilities and responsiveness of the
label: BODY

text: protective force; and 5) improving the defensive posture of DOE.
label: BODY

text: SSA also identifies and reports to senior DOE managers on site-specific and Department-wide issues
label: BODY

text: regarding security, cyber security, emergency management, environment, safety, and health,
label: BODY

text: classification and declassification programs and other programs using an efficient, systematic
label: BODY

text: independent oversight process that emphasizes performance and performance testing; conducts follow-
label: BODY

text: up activities to determine the effectiveness of corrective actions; and promotes line management self-
label: BODY

text: assessment activities, thereby enhancing overall performance in these program areas.  In addition, SSA
label: BODY

text: provides cross-organizational support to DOE efforts to resolve Defense Nuclear Facilities Safety
label: BODY

text: Board-related technical and management issues necessary to ensure public health and safety.
label: BODY

text: Major FY 2005 Achievements
label: BODY

text:  Design Basis Threat Site Assistance Visits – In partnership with the National Nuclear Security
label: BODY

text: Administration and Energy, Science, and Environment program and field locations; and Headquarters
label: BODY

text: policy organizations, SSA successfully completed site assistance visits at 11 DOE field sites with the
label: BODY

text: purpose of developing resource-efficient, sustainable protection strategies and assist in the development
label: BODY

text: of realistic budget submissions to support timely implementation of the revised Design Basis Threat
label: BODY

text: Policy.
label: BODY

text:  Streamlining DOE Safeguards and Security Directives – SSA has combined 27 safeguards and
label: BODY

text: security directives and several hundred guidance memoranda into an umbrella Order, 6 subject matter
label: BODY

text: manuals, and a reference manual.  The documents have been presented to the Deputy Secretary for
label: BODY

text: review and approval.  Streamlining this information will make it easier for users of the information to
label: BODY

text: better understand as well as to find a specific safeguard or security topics of interest; and will assure that
label: BODY

text: any changes are consistently coordinated with other policies.

text: Means and Strategies
label: BODY

text: SSA will achieve its mission by issuing clear, concise security policies, providing cutting-edge
label: BODY

text: technology-based security solutions, providing world-class training programs for security and safety
label: BODY

text: professionals, and applying rigorous independent oversight to departmental operations.
label: BODY

text: The SSA vision is to provide a sound foundation for protecting the Nation’s nuclear and energy assets
label: BODY

text: through advanced technology deployment and professional development.  This vision captures the SSA
label: BODY

text: role within the Department's overall security (including nuclear safeguards and security, cyber security,
label: BODY

text: and information security) and safety (including emergency management, and environment, safety, and
label: BODY

text: health) programs.  It also emphasizes the two areas that are necessary for the Department to achieve its
label: BODY

text: mission in the most efficient and effective manner, i.e., increased use of technology and effective
label: BODY

text: management and development of human capital.
label: BODY

text: In order to achieve its vision and perform its goals, it is necessary for SSA to maintain a highly qualified
label: BODY

text: workforce with the expertise and skills necessary to support, manage, and conduct security and
label: BODY

text: independent oversight operations now and in the foreseeable future.  The SSA workforce is, and must
label: BODY

text: be, comprised of world-class security and safety professionals grounded in science, engineering, and
label: BODY

text: technology led by effective program and project managers with exceptional communications and
label: BODY

text: marketing skills and supported by innovative resource management experts.
label: BODY

text: SSA requires the technical support of national-level experts to perform all its security, safety, and
label: BODY

text: independent oversight activities. Contractor support continues to be a practicable and cost–effective
label: BODY

text: means to provide a surge pool of technical experts, as opposed to expanding the Federal employee base.
label: BODY

text: The following external factor could affect SSA’s ability to achieve its strategic goal, revisions to the
label: BODY

text: Design Basis Threat Policy.  Revisions to the Design Basis Threat Policy based on changing geopolitical
label: BODY

text: conditions have the greatest potential for affecting SSA’s mission, priorities, and stated performance
label: BODY

text: targets.  Type and number of training courses developed and conducted, type and numbers of
label: BODY

text: technologies deployed, and scope of independent oversight appraisals performed are all dependent and
label: BODY

text: reliant upon current Design Basis Threat Policy timelines and depth of coverage.
label: BODY

text: SSA places a high degree of emphasis on working with DOE program and other staff offices to ensure
label: BODY

text: that security and safety issues are identified and adequately addressed.  SSA also interfaces with
label: BODY

text: organizations external to DOE to enhance the security posture of the United States as well as other
label: BODY

text: foreign states that maintain inventories of nuclear material.  SSA maintains strong relationships with the
label: BODY

text: following DOE organizations:
label: BODY

text:  Office of the Chief Information Officer (CIO)
label: BODY

text:  Office of Environment, Safety and Health (EH)
label: BODY

text:  Office of Intelligence (IN)
label: BODY

text:  Office of Counterintelligence (CN)
label: BODY

text:  National Nuclear Security Administration (NNSA)
label: BODY

text:  Office of Energy, Science, and Environment (ESE)
label: BODY

text:  DOE Inspector General (IG)
label: BODY

text: Validation and Verification
label: BODY

text: To validate and verify program performance, SSA will continuously monitor achievements for all
label: BODY

text: performance targets through weekly reporting mechanisms and periodic meetings with office directors.
label: BODY

text: In addition, appraisal performance targets will be verified and validated by the development of
label: BODY

text: documented reports.
label: BODY

text: Significant Policy or Program Shifts
label: BODY

text:  Civil Penalties for Classified Information Security Violations Implementation:  The Secretary of
label: BODY

text: Energy directed SSA to be responsible for implementing Section 234B to the Atomic Energy Act of
label: BODY

text: 1954 as specified in the final rule in 10 Code of Federal Regulations Part 824.  The rule implements
label: BODY

text: the requirements for issuing civil penalties for any person who enters into a contract or subcontract
label: BODY

text: with the Department and who violates any applicable rule, regulation, or Order issued by the
label: BODY

text: Secretary of Energy relating to the safeguarding or security of Restricted Data or other classified or
label: BODY

text: “sensitive information.”  Currently security directives are being reviewed to identify and insert
label: BODY

text: appropriate language to account for this activity.  SSA is also in the process of developing the means
label: BODY

text: and strategies for full implementation using the current Price Anderson Enforcement program as a
label: BODY

text: model.
label: BODY

text:  Increased Emphasis on Technology Deployment:  The deployment of security technologies is a
label: BODY

text: key strategy to avoid significant manpower increases that would otherwise be required to conform to
label: BODY

text: the Department’s updated Design Basis Threat Policy.  Towards that end, funding will be directed
label: BODY

text: for the purchase and installation of systems determined to have a positive impact on security
label: BODY

text: effectiveness as determined through the Design Basis Threat Site Assistance Visit analysis process.
label: BODY

text: The chosen technologies to be procured will be coordinated with the National Nuclear Security
label: BODY

text: Administration and other DOE program offices to ensure that security and safety requirements are
label: BODY

text: being addressed, that training and systems effectiveness procedures are in place, and that
label: BODY

text: promulgation of lessons learned throughout the complex is accomplished.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: issues.

label: BODY

text: DOE must implement effective security programs in an increasingly challenging threat environment.

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: uncertainties and establishing cooperation and useful dialog between managers and security
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Description
label: BODY

text: The mission of the Nuclear Safeguards and Security subprogram is to provide support to Federal staff
label: BODY

text: for security policy development, interpretation, and guidance; the development and conduct of security
label: BODY

text: and safety training; overseeing the development, application, and deployment of new security
label: BODY

text: technologies throughout DOE; and development and management of the Department’s classification and
label: BODY

text: controlled information program.  In addition, this subprogram provides for specialized security support
label: BODY

text: related to security issues and incidents tracking; nuclear materials accountability; foreign visits,
label: BODY

text: assignments, and travel; and foreign ownership and control programs.  Nuclear Safeguards and Security
label: BODY

text: also provides operational support to DOE Headquarters by managing the physical protection and
label: BODY

text: security of DOE facilities and information in the National Capital Area, and providing for the
label: BODY

text: Department’s Continuity of Government facilities.
label: BODY

text: The Program Goals of SSA will be accomplished not only through the efforts of the direct (GPRA Unit)
label: BODY

text: programs but with additional efforts from subprograms which support the GPRA Units in carrying out
label: BODY

text: their mission.  NSS performs the following functions in support of the overall mission of SSA.
label: BODY

text: Benefits
label: BODY

text: Safeguard and security policies and other guidance materials are developed and maintained to ensure the
label: BODY

text: Department’s programs are responsive to national security needs and changing threat environments, and
label: BODY

text: enable line management, through Headquarters and field organizations, to implement effective security
label: BODY

text: programs in a timely manner.  Security and safety training is provided to develop and maintain the
label: BODY

text: proficiency and competency of DOE safety and security personnel in support of the President’s and the
label: BODY

text: Department’s human capital management strategies thereby ensuring the protection of the public, the
label: BODY

text: departmental workforce, and critical assets and national security.  National laboratory resources are
label: BODY

text: utilized to develop and deploy the most promising and urgently needed technologies pertaining to
label: BODY

text: nuclear material safeguards and physical security, emphasizing engineering in place of administrative

text: The primary resource for performing nuclear material measurement activities is the New Brunswick
label: BODY

text: Laboratory (NBL), located in Argonne, IL.  Funding provides for NBL to purchase base materials
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: standards and comprehensive procedures to ensure that consistent results are obtained from various
label: BODY

text: destructive and nondestructive analysis techniques, thereby ensuring that DOE’s nuclear materials
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Global nuclear materials accountability activities provide for the maintenance and operation of the
label: BODY

text: Nuclear Materials Management and Safeguards System (NMMSS).  NMMSS is an electronic
label: BODY

text: information system comprised of software, hardware, procedures, and reports and meets the statutory
label: BODY

text: requirements of the Atomic Energy Act of 1954, as amended, and international treaties.  NMMSS is
label: BODY

text: the central component of the U.S. Government’s accounting system for the possession, use, and
label: BODY

text: shipment of nuclear material within the United States and abroad.  NMMSS is funded jointly by
label: BODY

text: DOE and the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) and is used to collate, maintain, and
label: BODY

text: report data regarding nuclear material inventories, material balances, and transactions of U.S.
label: BODY

text: Government-owned, foreign obligated, and privately owned nuclear material.  Reports derived from
label: BODY

text: NMMSS are provided to U.S. Government organizations including the NRC and the State
label: BODY

text: Department, the International Atomic Energy Agency, and foreign governments that receive U.S.-
label: BODY

text: owned nuclear materials.  Nuclear material management and safeguards data from more than 700
label: BODY

text: U.S. Government and commercial nuclear facilities is tracked on a “by site” basis.  NMMSS supports
label: BODY

text: the detection, assessment, and reporting of loss, diversion, or theft of nuclear materials.  NMMSS
label: BODY

text: supports implementation of the Design basis Threat Policy in the identification of attractive targets
label: BODY

text: for adversary attack, thereby assisting in the prioritization, development, and deployment of
label: BODY

text: protection for the most vulnerable assets.  Accounting for nuclear materials is required by DOE
label: BODY

text: Order 470.4, Safeguards and Security Program through DOE Manual 470.4-6, Nuclear Material
label: BODY

text: Control and Accountability (formerly DOE O 470 and DOE M 474.1-1A and -1B).

text: The primary tool developed to provide nuclear materials accountability within DOE at the site level
label: BODY

text: is the Local Area Nuclear Material Accountability Software (LANMAS). LANMAS is an SSA-
label: BODY

text: developed tool designed specifically to provide DOE sites with a standardized application for
label: BODY

text: tracking nuclear material by item and location.  The software application can be used on both stand-
label: BODY

text: alone and local area network computer systems.  LANMAS supports accurate and timely onsite
label: BODY

text: nuclear material inventory information and is used, in combination with other site security elements,
label: BODY

text: to account for, detect, assess, and report the theft or diversion of nuclear materials.  LANMAS also
label: BODY

text: has the potential to be integrated with site processing operations aligned with the Department’s
label: BODY

text: enterprise architecture to improve efficiencies and reduce costs associated with safeguarding and
label: BODY

text: managing nuclear materials.  Information managed by this software is used to account for day-to-day
label: BODY

text: activities at the site level, perform corporate-level quality assurance activities regarding material
label: BODY

text: transactions, and provide timely, information regarding the location of material throughout the DOE
label: BODY

text: complex for use in emergency response management. LANMAS demonstrates a cost savings for
label: BODY

text: DOE by minimizing duplication of software development.
label: BODY

text: The primary tool for inventorying radioactive sealed source materials throughout the Department is
label: BODY

text: the Radiological Source Registry and Tracking (RSRT) database. RSRT provides the Department
label: BODY

text: with an inventory tool to meet international guidance for registering and inventorying high-risk
label: BODY

text: sealed sources and assists in the determination of potential radiological sabotage targets.  The
label: BODY

text: database is updated annually through a Department-wide data call.  Information in the RSRT can be
label: BODY

text: used to monitor the location and use of sealed sources; detect and act on discrepancies in inventory,
label: BODY

text: assist in vulnerability studies and emergency response activities, and provide greater security and
label: BODY

text: management for high-risk radioactive sealed sources. The NRC is in the process of developing rules
label: BODY

text: for the control and accountability of sealed sources, as prescribed in the Energy Policy Act of 2005.
label: BODY

text: RSRT is the current mechanism that will be used by DOE to report to the NRC when the final rules
label: BODY

text: are promulgated.

text: Technology Development and Systems Deployment.......
label: BODY

text: The Technology Development and Systems Deployment activity provides technology-based solutions to
label: BODY

text: known security vulnerabilities throughout the DOE complex.  This activity provides technology–based
label: BODY

text: systems as an alternative to costly increases in manpower needed to implement the Design Basis Threat
label: BODY

text: Policy; and provides technologies to counter threats for which no current defensive capability exists.
label: BODY

text: The activity identifies and evaluates commercial technologies to ensure system performance is
label: BODY

text: commensurate with operational security requirements before such technologies are purchased and
label: BODY

text: deployed to protect critical national assets.  Funding provides for modifying existing technologies,
label: BODY

text: development of new technologies, and deploying technologies to meet security requirements.
label: BODY

text: Funding is used to addresses the broad spectrum of the Department’s security mission to include
label: BODY

text: physical security systems, protective force technologies and tactics, nuclear materials control and
label: BODY

text: accountability, as well as nuclear, chemical, and biological defenses.  The focus of this activity continues
label: BODY

text: to provide/deploy technical solutions in response to validated requirements identified through the Design
label: BODY

text: Basis Threat Site Assistance Visit process conducted by SSA in fiscal year 2005.  The primary security
label: BODY

text: capability areas to be addressed include: 1) early adversary detection through exterior sensors and
label: BODY

text: airborne platforms with sensor payloads capable of scanning several kilometers beyond the fence line,
label: BODY

text: and embedded sensors at the target location to instantaneously alarm to unauthorized tampering or
label: BODY

text: movement of materials; 2) support of an elite response force through advanced weaponry, distributed
label: BODY

text: situational awareness, all-weather target acquisition optics, non-pyrotechnic breaching kits, and
label: BODY

text: improved survivability for response force fighting positions, vehicles and command centers; and
label: BODY

text: 3) denial and neutralization capabilities at the target to include robotic weapons, incapacitating
label: BODY

text: technologies, or combinations thereof.
label: BODY

text: Funding also supports efforts to protect DOE facilities, assets, and personnel from terrorist use of
label: BODY

text: weapons of mass destruction (nuclear, biological, chemical and bulk explosives) in order to gain access
label: BODY

text: to nuclear materials or disrupt DOE capabilities critical to national security.  This is a multifaceted
label: BODY

text: initiative with sub-elements to address lethal chemical and explosives protection analysis at multiple
label: BODY

text: nuclear facilities; site-specific deployment and placement of chemical agent detectors throughout the
label: BODY

text: complex; deployment of lethal response capabilities impervious to weapons of mass destruction effects
label: BODY

text: within special nuclear material storage locations; and technical support for implementation of nuclear,
label: BODY

text: biological, and chemical protection technologies at critical security nodes such as central alarm stations
label: BODY

text: and protective force response rooms.
label: BODY

text: Included within this overall activity is funding for activities associated with the successful transition of
label: BODY

text: security technologies into Departmental operational facilities.  Funding provides for the resolution of
label: BODY

text: administrative, safety, and legal issues, in a timely manner to avoid significant delays in fielding
label: BODY

text: effective security technology solutions.

text: Description

text: The Security Investigations subprogram manages funding for security background investigations
label: BODY

text: associated with providing access authorization to DOE Federal and contract personnel who, in the
label: BODY

text: performance of their official duties, require access to classified information or certain quantities of
label: BODY

text: special nuclear material. Background investigations are required by Section 145 of the Atomic Energy
label: BODY

text: Act of 1954, as amended, and Executive Order 12968.  The investigations are performed and access
label: BODY

text: authorizations granted based on Title 10, Code of Federal Regulations, Part 710, Criteria and
label: BODY

text: Procedures for Determining Eligibility for Access to Classified Matter or Special Nuclear Material.

text: This subprogram provides for the centralized management of access control authorizations (clearances)

text:  Access Authorization Information Management ........
label: BODY

text: This activity provides for the management of all aspects of access authorization data.  The process of
label: BODY

text: investigating, granting, and subsequent management and tracking of access authorizations is data
label: BODY

text: intensive and requires the maintenance of large amounts of data for long periods of time, both for
label: BODY

text: personnel who are granted access authorizations and for those who are not.  The primary system for
label: BODY

text: performing this function is the electronic DOE Integrated Security System (e-DISS+), which
label: BODY

text: consists of a series of interrelated electronic databases and associated client applications and web
label: BODY

text: pages that automate the processing and tracking of access authorization requests and integrate the
label: BODY

text: access control process. An automated Applicant User Interface allows applicants to complete and
label: BODY

text: submit their Questionnaire for National Security Positions (Standard Form-86) over a secure web-
label: BODY

text: based system.  The Personnel Security Interface facilitates the collection of SF-86 data for review
label: BODY

text: and allows DOE security personnel to receive, process, review, and submit the information to OPM.
label: BODY

text: This process greatly reduces the amount of time spent on managing and preserving the integrity of
label: BODY

text: the data as the information flows between physical locations and organizations.  The e-DISS+ also
label: BODY

text: includes the Central Personnel Clearance Index database that maintains access authorization data at
label: BODY

text: the site and national level.  The Visitor Access Database and Classified Visitor Control System
label: BODY

text: contain data in centralized databases for nationwide access by DOE personnel and contractors
label: BODY

text: concerning access authorizations and inter-site visits for use in providing access to facilities and
label: BODY

text: information.  The e-DISS+ supports the President’s Management Agenda in the electronic
label: BODY

text: Government initiative, but does not duplicate the e-Clearance authorization initiative managed by
label: BODY

text: OPM.  Funding provides for the continued operation and maintenance, as well as modest upgrades in
label: BODY

text: the functionality of these systems, and for the maintenance of system user information.
label: BODY

text: days rather than waiting the 150 to 300 days for the Single Scope Background Investigations to be

label: BODY

text: Check with Credit.  The AAAP does not replace the Single Scope Background Investigations;

text: investigations continue even after the interim access authorization is granted. Funding provides for

text: operating costs, maintaining the information derived from the tests, and maintaining and operating

text:  Independent Oversight Activities................................
label: BODY

text: Independent oversight activities of security, cyber security, emergency management, and
label: BODY

text: environment, safety, and health programs throughout the Department directly relate to DOE national
label: BODY

text: security strategic and general goals.  Independent oversight appraisals are conducted to verify that
label: BODY

text: the Department’s security interests are protected, that the Department can effectively respond to
label: BODY

text: emergencies, and that site workers, the public, and the environment are protected from hazardous
label: BODY

text: operations and materials.  These appraisals provide accurate, comprehensive information and
label: BODY

text: analysis regarding the effectiveness, vulnerabilities, and trends of the Department’s security; cyber
label: BODY

text: security; emergency management; environment, safety, and health programs; and other critical
label: BODY

text: functions of interest to the Department Secretary, the Deputy Secretary, the Under Secretary, the
label: BODY

text: Administrator of the National Nuclear Security Administration, Congressional committees, and other
label: BODY

text: stakeholders, such as the Defense Nuclear Facilities Safety Board.
label: BODY

text: As required by DOE Order 470.2B, Independent Oversight and Performance Assurance Program,
label: BODY

text: dated October 21, 2002, the independent appraisal function is performed by personnel
label: BODY

text: organizationally independent of the DOE offices that develop and implement policies and programs
label: BODY

text: and, therefore, can objectively observe and report on these policies and programs as they relate to
label: BODY

text: departmental operations.  These appraisals complement but do not replace DOE line management’s
label: BODY

text: responsibility for security and safety program oversight and self-assessments, as required by
label: BODY

text: integrated security management and integrated safety management systems implemented throughout
label: BODY

text: the Department.  The appraisal processes utilized are governed by documented, formal protocols
label: BODY

text: addressing all phases of appraisal activities.  These processes are also conducive to changing
label: BODY

text: conditions and the needs of the Department.
label: BODY

text: Additionally, SSA continues to be actively involved in the development of Department-level
label: BODY

text: directives that establish overarching principles for oversight and identify DOE oversight activities
label: BODY

text: that involve assessing Federal and contractor performance.  These directives are closely linked to the
label: BODY

text: Department’s response to Defense Nuclear Facilities Safety Board Recommendation 2004-1,
label: BODY

text: Oversight of Complex High-Hazard Nuclear Operations.
label: BODY

text: Funding provides for contracted national-level experts to complement the Federal staff, to
label: BODY

text: implement the appraisal process, which emphasizes performance testing.  Appraisal personnel
label: BODY

text: observe operations and conduct performance tests to validate the effectiveness of safety and security
label: BODY

text: programs and policies.  Reports are developed documenting the assessment activities conducted, the
label: BODY

text: results of those assessments, and opportunities for improvement or findings.  Unclassified appraisal
label: BODY

text: reports and classified appraisal report titles are maintained on the SSA web site in order to share the
label: BODY

text: information throughout the Department.  Classified reports are maintained in a document control

text: Other Related Expenses provides support required for Federal and contractor staff to accomplish the

text: SSA mission.  Support includes the acquisition of security support and communications equipment,
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: The Extended Common Integrated Technology Environment initiative gathers the common information
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: these projects.  The information technology investments support the Federal staff at Headquarters by
label: BODY

text: providing support and maintenance of hardware, software, hotline, and other desktop maintenance.
label: BODY

text: Information technology hardware, connectivity, and support costs are based on a seat count and level of
label: BODY

text: service requested by SSA.
label: BODY

text: The maintenance of information technology systems exclusive to SSA is also part of this budget.  The
label: BODY

text: Classified Local Area Network is part of the consolidated infrastructure initiative.  It includes a Secret
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Defense classified network to effect coordination between the Departments.

label: BODY

text: for Federal employees) to maintain the skill base required by the position.

text: Preface
label: BODY

text: The Office of Environment, Safety and Health (EH) is committed to ensuring that the safety and health
label: BODY

text: of the DOE workforce and members of the public and the protection of the environment are integrated
label: BODY

text: into all Departmental activities.
label: BODY

text: Within the Other Defense Activities Appropriation, the Office of Environment, Safety and Health has
label: BODY

text: two programs: Environment, Safety and Health Programs (three subprograms) and Program Direction
label: BODY

text: (three subprograms).
label: BODY

text: This overview will describe Strategic Context, Mission, and Benefits.  These items together put this
label: BODY

text: appropriation in perspective.  The Annual Performance Results and Targets, Means and Strategies, and
label: BODY

text: Validation and Verification sections address how the goals will be achieved and how performance will
label: BODY

text: be measured.  Finally, this Overview will also address Significant Program Shifts.

text: Strategic Context
label: BODY

text: Following publication of the Administration’s National Energy Policy, the Department developed a
label: BODY

text: Strategic Plan that defines its mission, four strategic goals for accomplishing that mission, and seven
label: BODY

text: general goals to support the strategic goals.  As stated in the Departmental Strategic Plan, DOE’s
label: BODY

text: Strategic and General Goals will be accomplished not only through the efforts of the major program
label: BODY

text: offices in the Department but with additional effort from offices which support the programs in carrying
label: BODY

text: out the mission.  The Office of Environment, Safety and Health performs critical functions which
label: BODY

text: directly support the mission of the Department.  These functions include:
label: BODY

text: Environment – Ensure the protection of the environmental resources affected by DOE activities.
label: BODY

text: Safety – Operate to industry standards where they are relevant and available and provide regulations
label: BODY

text: for those operations that are unique to DOE; perform at a level equal to or better than private
label: BODY

text: industry.
label: BODY

text: Health – Promotes the health and safety of DOE’s workers and communities surrounding DOE sites;
label: BODY

text: to develop comprehensive and effective safety and health policy for DOE workplace hazards, and to
label: BODY

text: conduct studies and medical screening to understand the effects of radiation, chemical and other
label: BODY

text: potential hazards of DOE operations on humans.
label: BODY

text: Corporate Performance Assessment – Provide environment, safety and health performance trending,
label: BODY

text: analysis, and measures to ensure DOE’s ES&H goals are accomplished.  Performance trending and
label: BODY

text: analysis also focuses resources and senior management attention on significant and emerging issues.
label: BODY

text: Ensure operating experience, including lessons learned and best practices, are identified and shared
label: BODY

text: throughout the DOE to continuously improve performance and prevent adverse events from
label: BODY

text: recurring.  Improve the quality of worker radiation exposure measurements, thus helping to prevent
label: BODY

text: future radiation exposure related litigation and compensation programs, through implementation of
label: BODY

text: the 10 CFR 835 required DOE Laboratory Accreditation Program.  Provide the corporate framework
label: BODY

text: to ensure quality assurance is properly applied to all DOE operations and that work is performed
label: BODY

text: safely and reliably.  Provide the necessary policy, guidance, and corporate direction.  Provide the
label: BODY

text: Mixed Analyte Performance Evaluation Program to ensure quality in environmental measurements
label: BODY

text: in support of DOE cleanup activities.  The Information Management programs ensure that
label: BODY

text: information technology is acquired and information resources are managed in a manner that
label: BODY

text: implements the policies and procedures of legislation and the President’s Management Agenda.
label: BODY

text: Nuclear/Worker Safety Enforcement - Implement DOE’s congressional mandates to investigate
label: BODY

text: safety conditions or events and apply enforcement sanctions to contractors for unsafe actions or
label: BODY

text: conditions that violate DOE nuclear safety and worker safety requirements for protecting workers
label: BODY

text: and the public.
label: BODY

text: Nuclear Safety Research – Develops, prioritizes and approves an annual nuclear safety research plan
label: BODY

text: that meets the needs of the DOE Energy, Science and Environment (ESE) Central Technical
label: BODY

text: Authority (CTA) and the National Nuclear Security Administration (NNSA) CTA, and that takes
label: BODY

text: into account information obtained through the Operating Experience Program; maintains adequate
label: BODY

text: numbers of technically competent personnel necessary to fulfill nuclear safety research
label: BODY

text: responsibilities; integrates existing nuclear safety research being performed both inside and outside
label: BODY

text: the DOE; and participates in and represents DOE at national and international nuclear safety

label: BODY

text: Mission
label: BODY

text: The mission of the EH is to provide the corporate leadership, performance goals, assistance, policies,
label: BODY

text: programs and feedback to enable the Department of Energy to excel in mission performance while
label: BODY

text: achieving excellence in safety and environmental stewardship.
label: BODY

text: Environment, Safety and Health performs critical functions which directly support the mission of the
label: BODY

text: Department.  These functions include providing technical support and assistance; assessing
label: BODY

text: performance; ensuring quality assurance is properly applied; developing corporate policy, guidance,
label: BODY

text: rules, orders and standards; and supporting an effective collaborative radiological and non radiological
label: BODY

text: health studies program.
label: BODY

text: Benefits
label: BODY

text: DOE works to identify health concerns, investigate health effects from similar operations, integrate new
label: BODY

text: occupational health understanding into DOE operations, and support the Department of Labor in
label: BODY

text: implementing the Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act.  EH leverages
label: BODY

text: its resources and personnel to provide DOE’s line management programs with essential environment,
label: BODY

text: safety and health performance expectations: environment, safety and health performance measures and
label: BODY

text: analysis; management tools to promote the safe conduct of work, including the Department’s Quality
label: BODY

text: Assurance Program; and guidance for the protection of the environment in and around DOE sites.
label: BODY

text: Integral to the Department’s success is EH’s skill in fostering increased awareness and providing
label: BODY

text: support to line management throughout the Department, using open communications, coordinating with
label: BODY

text: other industry and governmental organizations, and performance feedback on environmental, safety, and
label: BODY

text: health activities, to provide the safety infrastructure that allows for and promotes the safe and
label: BODY

text: environmentally responsible conduct of work.  The Department of Energy Laboratory Accreditation
label: BODY

text: Program promotes worker confidence that work is being accomplished safely, and provides the quality
label: BODY

text: assurance documentation that could help prevent future worker radiation exposure litigation or
label: BODY

text: additional worker exposure compensation programs.
label: BODY

text: Means and Strategies
label: BODY

text: The Office of Environment, Safety and Health will pursue the following means and strategies:
label: BODY

text: Ensure DOE excellence in environment, safety and health.
label: BODY

text: Ensure the protection of the environmental resources affected by DOE activities.
label: BODY

text: Ensure DOE facilities operate safely.
label: BODY

text: Ensure the safety and health of workers at DOE facilities and the communities that surround them.
label: BODY

text: Ensure accountability and continuous improvement in environment, safety, and health performance.
label: BODY

text: Ensure EH meets the goals of the President’s Management Agenda, initiative 4, “Expanded
label: BODY

text: Electronic Government.”
label: BODY

text: Ensure EH organizational effectiveness.
label: BODY

text: Ensure continuance of record research activities in support of the Department of Labor as required
label: BODY

text: by Part E of Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program. (Public Law 108-375).
label: BODY

text: Validation and Verification
label: BODY

text: To validate and verify program performance, the Office of Environment, Safety and Health will conduct
label: BODY

text: various internal and external reviews and audits.  Programmatic activities are subject to continuing
label: BODY

text: reviews by the Congress, the Government Accountability Office, the Department’s Inspector General,
label: BODY

text: and the Defense Nuclear Facilities Safety Board.  In addition, Headquarters senior managers conduct in-
label: BODY

text: depth reviews of cost and schedule to ensure activities are on-track and within budget.
label: BODY

text: Significant Policy or Program Shifts
label: BODY

text: Environment, Safety and Health significant policy and program shifts are as follows:
label: BODY

text: On December 17, 2004, in response to Defense Nuclear Facilities Safety Board Recommendation
label: BODY

text: 2004-1, former Deputy Secretary for Energy McSlarrow directed the following organizational
label: BODY

text: changes for the Department to better focus departmental awareness and management of issues
label: BODY

text: related to nuclear safety.  To enhance the focus of environment, safety, and health in the Department,
label: BODY

text: the Office of Environment, Safety and Health (EH) is now reporting directly to the Deputy Secretary
label: BODY

text: of Energy.  EH is the corporate environmental, safety and health (ES&H) officer and responsible for
label: BODY

text: making ES&H policy and providing technical interpretations of it.
label: BODY

text: In FY 2006, the Office of Environmental Management will transfer the management of High
label: BODY

text: Efficiency Particulate Air (HEPA) filter testing service responsibilities to the Office of Environment,
label: BODY

text: Safety and Health.  Financial responsibility will transfer in FY 2007. This Quality Assurance
label: BODY

text: function ensures HEPA filters used at DOE’s nuclear facilities meet strict criteria to ensure public
label: BODY

text: and worker safety and implements a Defense Nuclear Facilities Safety Board commitment to test
label: BODY

text: 100 percent of all HEPA filters prior to use in defense nuclear facilities.
label: BODY

text: The Office of Environment, Safety and Health needs to significantly strengthen the Department’s
label: BODY

text: Operating Experience Program to meet a formal commitment to the Defense Nuclear Facilities
label: BODY

text: Safety Board.  This is a critical aspect of the Department’s safety management system for operations
label: BODY

text: feedback and improvement.
label: BODY

text: Mission
label: BODY

text: The mission of the Office of Environment, Safety and Health (EH) is to provide leadership and
label: BODY

text: Departmental direction through line programs to protect the workers, the public, and the environment.
label: BODY

text: Benefits
label: BODY

text: Within the Other Defense Activities appropriation, EH plays a key role in achieving the Department’s
label: BODY

text: mission.  A commitment to excellence is achieved by continuously striving for improvement through:
label: BODY

text: developing meaningful programs and policies; performance trending and analysis to ensure senior
label: BODY

text: management operational awareness of safety issues; providing leadership and assistance to DOE Field
label: BODY

text: operations to ensure the complex learns from each others mistakes and shares best operations practices;
label: BODY

text: enforcing nuclear safety and ensuring quality assurance programs, including policies and standards, are
label: BODY

text: in place and functioning properly across the Department.  Open communication, participation, and
label: BODY

text: performance feedback on EH activities from affected parties are integral to EH’s success.  The hallmark

text: Description
label: BODY

text: Corporate Safety Programs serve a crosscutting safety function for the Department and its stakeholders
label: BODY

text: in assuring excellence and continuous improvement in environment, safety and health in the conduct of
label: BODY

text: its missions and activities.  Elements that comprise Corporate Safety Programs are:  Performance
label: BODY

text: Assessment, the Quality Assurance Program, Information Management, the Facility Safety Program,
label: BODY

text: Price-Anderson Enforcement, the Analytical Services Program, and the new Nuclear Safety Research
label: BODY

text: Program.  In June 2005, the Secretary signed the Department’s Implementation Plan (Rev. 1) in
label: BODY

text: response to DNFSB Recommendation 2004-1.  DOE has committed to enhance the nuclear safety
label: BODY

text: research function within the Department.
label: BODY

text: Benefits
label: BODY

text: These programs conduct activities that are critical to the Department’s ability to monitor the status of
label: BODY

text: environment, safety and health across the complex; to proactively identify and resolve emerging safety
label: BODY

text: issues and adverse trends; and to assure continuous improvement in the protection of workers,
label: BODY

text: communities, and the environment from the hazards associated with changing DOE missions and
label: BODY

text: activities.  The program also serves our national security mission by assuring the effective integration of
label: BODY

text: safety and success of mission programs, including security of our energy infrastructure, research and
label: BODY

text: development, stockpile stewardship, and accelerated cleanup of DOE’s excess sites and environmental
label: BODY

text: contamination.  Nuclear Safety Research will evaluate and prioritize nuclear safety research needs;
label: BODY

text: allocate resources; manage research programs; assess the effectiveness of regulatory programs; develop
label: BODY

text: technical basis for nuclear directives; maintain nuclear safety testing and analysis capabilities; integrate
label: BODY

text: results in the areas of nuclear facility design and construction, safety analysis, safe nuclear operations,
label: BODY

text: integrate existing nuclear safety research being performed both inside and outside the DOE; and
label: BODY

text: development of technically sound safety directives.

text: The Performance Assessment Program includes (1) Operating Experience, and (2) Performance
label: BODY

text: Trending and Analysis.  Trending and analysis of DOE’s performance in protecting the public, workers,
label: BODY

text: and the environment is conducted by synthesizing operational information to support senior
label: BODY

text: management decision-making, resource allocation, and continuous ES&H improvement across the DOE
label: BODY

text: complex. This includes setting ES&H performance expectations and performance measurements for
label: BODY

text: continuous improvement.  Performance Trending and Analysis also develops and implements improved
label: BODY

text: methods for using current databases and communicating information (e.g., data mining and display
label: BODY

text: capabilities); uses state-of-the-art commercial experience to identify and use leading performance
label: BODY

text: measures to leverage safety performance; and provides analysis of safety performance tailored to
label: BODY

text: nuclear safety (i.e., Central Technical Authorities (CTAs) Chief of Nuclear Safety and Nuclear Safety
label: BODY

text: Research) functions in FY 2007.

text: The Program implements a significantly enhanced and adequate Operating Experience activity DOE-
label: BODY

text: wide.  Operating Experience is crucial in the Department’s follow-up to internal and external accidents
label: BODY

text: and events to ensure they do not recur.  In FY 2007, EH will fully implement a functional Operating
label: BODY

text: Experience program that meets Defense Nuclear Facilities Safety Board (DNFSB) 2004-1
label: BODY

text: commitments; significantly improves DOE/contractor awareness and resolution of operational safety
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: contractor worker safety and their day-to-day performance; and monitor and evaluate the effectiveness
label: BODY

text: of contractor actions that use Operating Experience information.  This program is also responsible for
label: BODY

text: the DOE Suspect/Counterfeit Items identification and investigation process which also supports
label: BODY

text: Department of Justice and other Federal Agency investigations of related fraud.  This activity is an
label: BODY

text: ongoing high priority commitment made to the DNFSB by the Secretary.

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: In FY 2006, the Office of Environmental Management will transfer the management of HEPA filter
label: BODY

text: testing services responsibilities to the Office of Environment, Safety and Health.  Financial
label: BODY

text: responsibility will transfer in FY 2007.  The Filter Test Facility (FTF) will improve the Department’s
label: BODY

text: quality assurance function to serve all Departmental programs.  DOE has committed to conduct 100
label: BODY

text: percent independent testing of HEPA filters installed in safety systems (safety class and safety
label: BODY

text: significant) and habitability systems.  The Office of Environmental Management FTF operations
label: BODY

text: resulted in an average of 2,600 filters tested annually from DOE nuclear facilities.  The FTF operation is
label: BODY

text: necessary because of the critical nature of the filter usage in DOE facilities in mitigating radioactive
label: BODY

text: exposure to the public, workers and the environment.  DOE-STD-3020-97, Specifications for HEPA
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: DOE funds the Department of Health and Human Services to conduct health studies and public
label: BODY

text: health activities relevant to DOE workers and residents of communities neighboring DOE sites
label: BODY

text: across the United States.  These activities are conducted by the National Institute for Occupational
label: BODY

text: Safety and Health (NIOSH), the National Center for Environmental Health (NCEH), and the Agency
label: BODY

text: for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry (ATSDR) through three interagency agreements.  In FY
label: BODY

text: 2006, NIOSH communicated results to workers concerning four studies at five DOE sites.  Study
label: BODY

text: results provide information that is designed to enhance the understanding of risks associated with
label: BODY

text: radiation-induced health effects to over 800,000 workers.  In FY 2006, NCEH concluded an
label: BODY

text: historical environmental dose reconstruction at one of DOE’s major production sites that evaluated
label: BODY

text: the risk to the public of past releases of radiation and chemicals in communities around DOE sites.
label: BODY

text: Results of historical dose reconstructions are used to estimate exposure-related health risks.  In FY
label: BODY

text: 2006, ATSDR finalized seven out of eight public health assessments of the Oak Ridge Reservation.

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Preface
label: BODY

text: During FY 2007, the Department continues its efforts to reduce risk to human health and the
label: BODY

text: environment at its contaminated sites and manage its pension and benefit responsibilities for former
label: BODY

text: contractor personnel.  By conducting the long-term surveillance and maintenance of remediated sites
label: BODY

text: and ensuring pension and benefit continuity, the Office of Legacy Management allows Environmental
label: BODY

text: Management to concentrate on further risk reduction and site closure.
label: BODY

text: Within the Energy and Water, Other Defense Activities appropriation, the Office of Legacy
label: BODY

text: Management (LM) has one program: Legacy Management.
label: BODY

text: This Overview will describe Strategic Context, Mission, Benefits, Strategic Goals, and Funding by
label: BODY

text: General Goals.  These items together put the appropriation in perspective.  The Annual Performance
label: BODY

text: Results and Targets, Means and Strategies, and Validation and Verification sections address how the
label: BODY

text: goals will be achieved and how performance will be measured.  Finally, this Overview will address
label: BODY

text: Significant Program Shifts.
label: BODY

text: Strategic Context
label: BODY

text: Following publication of the Administration’s National Energy Policy, the Department developed a
label: BODY

text: Strategic Plan that defines its mission, four strategic goals for accomplishing that mission, and seven
label: BODY

text: a Reflects a 1 percent rescission in accordance with P.L. 109-148, Emergency Supplemental Appropriations to Address
label: BODY

text: Hurricanes in the Gulf of Mexico and Pandemic Influenza, 2006
label: BODY

text: FY 2007 Congressional Budget
label: BODY

text: general goals to support the strategic goals.  Each appropriation has developed quantifiable goals to
label: BODY

text: support the general goals.  Thus, the “goal cascade” is the following:
label: BODY

text: Department Mission ĺ Strategic Goal (25 yrs) ĺ General Goal (10-15 yrs) ĺ Program Goal (GPRA
label: BODY

text: Unit) (10-15 yrs)
label: BODY

text: To provide a concrete link between budget, performance, and reporting, the Department developed a
label: BODY

text: “GPRA Unit” concept.  Within DOE, a GPRA Unit defines a major activity or group of activities that
label: BODY

text: support the core mission and aligns resources with specific goals.  Each GPRA Unit has completed or
label: BODY

text: will complete a Program Assessment Rating Tool (PART).  A unique program goal was developed for
label: BODY

text: each GPRA Unit.  A numbering scheme has been established for tracking performance and reporting.
label: BODY

text: The goal cascade accomplishes two things.  First, it ties major activities for each program to successive
label: BODY

text: goals and, ultimately, to DOE’s mission.  This helps ensure the Department focuses its resources on
label: BODY

text: fulfilling its mission.  Second, the cascade allows DOE to track progress against quantifiable goals and
label: BODY

text: to tie resources to each goal at any level in the cascade.  Thus, the cascade facilitates the integration of
label: BODY

text: budget and performance information in support of the GRPA and the President’s Management Agenda
label: BODY

text: (PMA).
label: BODY

text: Mission
label: BODY

text: The mission of the Office of Legacy Management is to manage the department’s post-closure
label: BODY

text: responsibilities and ensure the future protection of human health and the environment.   This Office has
label: BODY

text: control and custody for legacy lands, structures, and facilities and is responsible for maintaining them at
label: BODY

text: levels suitable for their long-term use.
label: BODY

text: Benefits
label: BODY

text: The greatest benefit of the Office of Legacy Management is to serve as a visible demonstration of the
label: BODY

text: Department’s resolve to honor its responsibilities for the communities near its remediated facilities and
label: BODY

text: for the former contractor work force.
label: BODY

text: The Office of Legacy Management programs provide benefits to the Department following mission
label: BODY

text: change or site closure.  For sites where cleanup is completed, Legacy Management programs ensure that
label: BODY

text: the remediation measures implemented during closure are protecting human health and the environment,
label: BODY

text: that labor responsibilities for the contractor work force are being satisfied, and that other Departmental
label: BODY

text: legacy responsibilities are met.  By managing the real and personal property assets that remain after
label: BODY

text: cleanup and closure, Legacy Management helps the Department reduce the magnitude of its physical
label: BODY

text: resource management, the costs associated with such management, and actively promotes the beneficial
label: BODY

text: reuse of those mission excess properties.
label: BODY

text: Strategic, General, and Program Goals
label: BODY

text: The Department’s Strategic Plan identifies four strategic goals (one each for defense, energy, science,
label: BODY

text: and environmental aspects of the mission plus seven general goals that tie to the strategic goals.  The
label: BODY

text: Other Defense Activities appropriation supports the following goal:
label: BODY

text: Environment Strategic Goal:  To protect the environment by providing a responsible resolution to the
label: BODY

text: environmental legacy of the Cold War and by providing for the permanent disposal of high-level
label: BODY

text: radioactive waste.
label: BODY

text: FY 2007 Congressional Budget
label: BODY

text: General Goal 6, Environmental Management:  Accelerate cleanup of nuclear weapons manufacturing
label: BODY

text: and testing sites, completing cleanup of 108 contaminated sites by 2025.
label: BODY

text: The programs funded within the Other Defense Activities appropriation have one Program Goal that
label: BODY

text: contributes to the General Goal in the “goal cascade”.  This goal is:
label: BODY

text: Program Goal 06.26.00.00:  Legacy Management – By 2015, the Office of legacy Management will be
label: BODY

text: responsible for:  the cost effective management of land, structures, facilities and/or records for over 120
label: BODY

text: sites; employee benefits for the Department’s former contractor work force at seven sites; and the
label: BODY

text: disposal of real property at five sites.
label: BODY

text: Contribution to General Goal
label: BODY

text: Within the Program Goal for the Legacy Management program, there are four subgoals that contribute
label: BODY

text: to the general goal.  These subgoals are:
label: BODY

text: Protect human health and the environment through effective and efficient long-term surveillance and
label: BODY

text: maintenance – Activities associated with this subgoal contribute to the general goal by managing the
label: BODY

text: long-term surveillance and maintenance at sites where remediation has been essentially completed,
label: BODY

text: allowing the Environmental Management program to concentrate its efforts on continuing to
label: BODY

text: accelerate cleanup and site closure resulting in reduced risks to human health and the environment
label: BODY

text: and reduced landlord costs.
label: BODY

text: Preserve, protect, and make accessible legacy records and information – These activities assist the
label: BODY

text: other activities by providing a central records management capability.  This work directly supports
label: BODY

text: the administration of the Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act
label: BODY

text: (EEOICPA) and is responsive to Freedom of Information Act and Privacy Act requests.  This
label: BODY

text: enables more efficient operation of the other activities and is needed to defend the Department
label: BODY

text: against future liability claims.
label: BODY

text: Support an effective and efficient work force structured to accomplish Departmental missions and
label: BODY

text: assure contractor worker pension and medical benefits – The Legacy Management program manages
label: BODY

text: the Department’s labor relations and oversees some pension and benefit programs to meet the
label: BODY

text: Department’s contractual commitments.  By managing these activities, the Office of Legacy
label: BODY

text: Management enables the Office of Environmental Management to focus on further risk reduction by
label: BODY

text: remediating other sites.
label: BODY

text: Manage legacy land and assets, emphasizing protective real and personal property reuse and
label: BODY

text: disposition – These activities promote more efficient management of remediated resources.  This
label: BODY

text: allows more resources to be focused on further risk reduction.
label: BODY

text: Means and Strategies
label: BODY

text: The Legacy Management Program will use various means and strategies to achieve its program goal.
label: BODY

text: However, various external factors may impact the ability to achieve the goal.  The program also
label: BODY

text: performs collaborative activities to help meet its goal.
label: BODY

text: The Department will implement the following means:
label: BODY

text: Long-term surveillance and maintenance will be performed in accordance with the regulatory
label: BODY

text: decisions for each site.  Activities range from maintaining records to routine inspections and
label: BODY

text: maintenance at sites where remediation measures are substantially completed.
label: BODY

text: Adequate staffing will be maintained to oversee the program.  A large portion of the surveillance
label: BODY

text: and maintenance and payment of the contractor pensions and benefits will be performed by
label: BODY

text: contractors.
label: BODY

text: The Department will implement the following strategies:
label: BODY

text: The Office of Legacy Management (LM) will only accept responsibility for sites where remediation
label: BODY

text: has been substantially completed.
label: BODY

text: The following external factors could affect LM’s ability to achieve its strategic goal:
label: BODY

text: Significant changes in remedy performance could cause the site to be returned to EM for further
label: BODY

text: remediation.
label: BODY

text: In conducting the program’s surveillance and maintenance functions, LM performs the following
label: BODY

text: collaborative activities:
label: BODY

text: Evaluation of remedy performance, as determined by surveillance and maintenance activities, is
label: BODY

text: coordinated with regulators, local communities, and other stakeholders.
label: BODY

text: Validation and Verification
label: BODY

text: The Department is operating a performance tracking system to measure performance.  The Office of the
label: BODY

text: Chief Financial Officer has developed action plans for the primary functions.  Quarterly updates for sites
label: BODY

text: where surveillance and maintenance has been conducted are reported using an automated system.
label: BODY

text: For payments of medical benefits or other activities not tracked by the automated system, the Office of
label: BODY

text: Legacy Management will obtain quarterly updates to judge progress of the programs.
label: BODY

text: The Legacy Management program has not performed a Program Assessment Rating Tool (PART)
label: BODY

text: evaluation to date but such a review and the measures resulting from it would also provide verification.
label: BODY

text: The observed results of surveillance and maintenance activities will be documented as annual inspection
label: BODY

text: and compliance reports and retained as long as specified in Federal requirements for records retention.
label: BODY

text: To validate and verify program performance, LM will conduct various internal and external reviews and
label: BODY

text: audits.  LM’s programmatic activities are subject to continuing reviews by the Congress, the
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Government Accountability Office, the Department’s Inspector General, the U.S. Environmental
label: BODY

text: Protection Agency, U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission, state environmental and health agencies, and
label: BODY

text: the Department’s Office of Engineering and Construction Management.  Additionally, LM Headquarters
label: BODY

text: senior management staff conduct quarterly, in-depth reviews of cost, schedule, and scope to ensure
label: BODY

text: projects are on-track and within budget.
label: BODY

text: Significant Policy or Program Shifts
label: BODY

text: By the start of FY 2007, the Office of Environmental Management (EM) will have completed active
label: BODY

text: cleanup of several major sites throughout the Department of Energy complex.  Management of these
label: BODY

text: sites will be transferred to the Office of Legacy Management (LM).  Management activities will
label: BODY

text: include legacy functions of long-term surveillance and maintenance, long-term response actions,
label: BODY

text: oversight and management of pension and benefit payments for former contractor retirees, and
label: BODY

text: records management.  The cumulative effect of these transfers will result in an increase of the LM
label: BODY

text: budget by approximately 150 percent.  However, this increase in the LM budget will be matched by
label: BODY

text: a corresponding decrease in the EM budget.
label: BODY

text: The largest transfer will be for the Rocky Flats site near Denver, CO.  Active cleanup will be
label: BODY

text: completed and all other activities except for legacy function at this major site have ended.  At
label: BODY

text: this site, LM will be managing all activities identified above.
label: BODY

text: The Fernald Site near Cincinnati, OH, is another major transfer.  Like Rocky Flats, active
label: BODY

text: cleanup will be completed and LM will be managing all the legacy functions identified above.
label: BODY

text: A group of sites known collectively as the Nevada offsites, will be also be a major transfer.  The
label: BODY

text: sites involved in this category are:  Amchitka site, AK; Rio Blanco and Rulison sites, CO;
label: BODY

text: Gasbuggy and Gnome-Coach sites, NM; Salmon site, MS; and Project Shoal and Central
label: BODY

text: Nevada Test Area, NV.  LM will be managing the legacy functions of long-term surveillance
label: BODY

text: and management, long-term response actions, and records management for these sites.  There
label: BODY

text: are no pension or benefit payments involved for any of these sites.
label: BODY

text: At the same time that the program magnitude is significantly increasing, the Office of Legacy
label: BODY

text: Management (LM) is involved in an internal evaluation of its own management needs.  LM is
label: BODY

text: evaluating the anticipated work load from the increased activities and its existing skill mix in an
label: BODY

text: effort to effectively manage its activities.  So far, this review has resulted in significant efficiencies
label: BODY

text: for FY 2007 from FY 2006, despite the increase in the program scope and magnitude.
label: BODY

text: To accommodate the records management functions, the FY 2007 request supports the centralization
label: BODY

text: of Legacy Archives and Information activities from various sites across the country to a single
label: BODY

text: location to ensure a more streamlined management approach.
label: BODY

text: Site Description
label: BODY

text: Fernald Site
label: BODY

text: The Fernald site is located in southern Ohio and is one of the facilities targeted by the Office of
label: BODY

text: Environmental Management for closure in FY 2006.  Funding in FY 2007 will be for the purposes of
label: BODY

text: long-term surveillance and maintenance and post-closure contractor retiree pensions and benefits.
label: BODY

text: Grand Junction Office
label: BODY

text: The Grand Junction Office is located in western Colorado.  The oversight of the long-term surveillance
label: BODY

text: and maintenance program at sites distributed throughout the Western states is the staff’s primary
label: BODY

text: function.  The long-term surveillance and maintenance activities managed from this office include
label: BODY

text: environmental monitoring, long-term treatment of contaminants, maintaining site security, and asset
label: BODY

text: disposition.  During FY 2007, in addition to surveillance and maintenance activities, preparation for
label: BODY

text: transferring the Mound site from Environmental Management to Legacy Management will also occur.
label: BODY

text: Morgantown Office
label: BODY

text: The Morgantown Office is located in Morgantown, WV.  Program functions that are the focus of staff at
label: BODY

text: that location include long-term surveillance and maintenance activities in the Eastern and Midwestern
label: BODY

text: states and, beginning in FY 2007, legacy archives and information management activities to support the
label: BODY

text: missions of the Office of Legacy Management.  During FY 2005 and FY 2006, design, site selection,
label: BODY

text: land acquisition, and construction of a records storage facility were major work elements.
label: BODY

text: Mound Plant
label: BODY

text: The Mound Plant is one of the facilities targeted by the Office of Environmental Management for
label: BODY

text: closure in FY 2007.  Successful site cleanup will result in the closure and turnover of 24 buildings and
label: BODY

text: 306 acres to the Miamisburg-Mound Community Improvement Corporation for private sector
label: BODY

text: development.
label: BODY

text: Pinellas Plant
label: BODY

text: The Pinellas Site is a former weapons facility located in Pinellas, FL, which is in the Tampa-St.
label: BODY

text: Petersburg metropolitan area.  The facility has been completely closed and the property sold to the local
label: BODY

text: community reuse organization.  The Legacy Management program provides pension and benefits
label: BODY

text: payments for the former contractor work force as well as assisted the community reuse organization as a
label: BODY

text: focal point to stabilize the local economy.   A portion of the funding in FY 2005 (approximately $ 1.2M)
label: BODY

text: was for assistance for the community reuse organization.
label: BODY

text: Rocky Flats Field Office
label: BODY

text: The Rocky Flats facility is located about ten miles north of Golden, CO.  It is one of the facilities
label: BODY

text: targeted by the Office of Environmental Management for closure in FY 2006.  Funding in FY 2005 was
label: BODY

text: to assist in forming a Local Stakeholder Organization for that facility.  Funding in FY 2007 will be for
label: BODY

text: the purposes of long-term surveillance and maintenance and post-closure contractor retiree pensions and
label: BODY

text: benefits.
