text: Mission
label: BODY

text: The mission of the Office of Legacy Management is to manage the Department’s post-closure
label: BODY

text: responsibilities and ensure the future protection of human health and the environment.  This Office has
label: BODY

text: control and custody for legacy land, structure, and facilities and is responsible for maintaining them at
label: BODY

text: levels suitable for their long-term use.  The activities that are used to accomplish this mission include:
label: BODY

text: (1) conduct long-term surveillance and maintenance (also referred to as long-term stewardship) at DOE
label: BODY

text: facilities where remediation measures have been substantially completed; (2) oversee the management
label: BODY

text: of pensions and benefits for former contractor employees; (3) perform storage, retrieval, and
label: BODY

text: management of all records necessary for legacy management activities, (4) administer the
label: BODY

text: Environmental Justice program, and, (5) dispose of assets no longer needed for the Department’s
label: BODY

text: missions.
label: BODY

text: Beginning in FY 2005, the cost of conducting External Independent Reviews (EIRs) for Capital Asset
label: BODY

text: Projects greater than $5 million within the Legacy Management Program, have been funded by this
label: BODY

text: program.  Examples of EIRs include conducting Performance Baseline EIRs prior to Critical Decision-2
label: BODY

text: (CD-2) to verify the accuracy of cost and schedule baseline estimates and conducting Construction/
label: BODY

text: Execution Readiness EIRs, which are done for all Major System projects prior to CD-3.  These funds,
label: BODY

text: which are managed by the Office of Engineering and Construction Management, are exclusively used
label: BODY

text: for EIRs directly related to these projects funded within the Legacy Management program.  Beginning
label: BODY

text: Benefits
label: BODY

text: The Legacy Management program contains important elements to assist the Office of Environmental
label: BODY

text: Management achieve the strategic goal of providing a resolution to the environmental legacy of the Cold
label: BODY

text: War.  As the Office of Environmental Management completes its cleanup activities, certain aspects of
label: BODY

text: the Department’s responsibilities remain.  These activities include:  long-term groundwater pump and
label: BODY

text: treat operations, remedy surveillance and maintenance, records management, and long-term retirement
label: BODY

text: pension and benefits for contractor personnel.  A long-term commitment to manage the resources and
label: BODY

text: activities beyond the completion of active remediation is required.  The activities of the Legacy
label: BODY

text: Management program ensure that these Departmental responsibilities are addressed and the Office of
label: BODY

text: Environmental Management is able to concentrate its efforts on cleanup and risk reduction.
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Assumed responsibility for the following Environmental Management sites:  General Atomics,
label: BODY

text: University of Missouri Research Reactor, Project Chariot, and Geothermal Test Facility.

text: Description
label: BODY

text: The objectives of the Legacy Management subprogram are to conduct long-term surveillance and
label: BODY

text: maintenance (also referred to as long-term stewardship) at DOE facilities where remediation measures
label: BODY

text: have been substantially completed, oversee the management of pensions and benefits for former
label: BODY

text: contractor employees, perform storage, retrieval, and management of all records necessary for legacy
label: BODY

text: management activities, and administer the environmental justice program.  These activities are
label: BODY

text: performed for the purpose of supporting the Department’s commitments contained in records of
label: BODY

text: decision, contracts, and legal agreements.
label: BODY

text: Benefits
label: BODY

text: The Legacy Management subprogram contains the essential elements to assist the Office of
label: BODY

text: Environmental Management achieve the strategic goal of providing a resolution to the environmental
label: BODY

text: legacy of the Cold War and ensure that the Department fulfills its long-term commitments to protect the
label: BODY

text: environment and to ensure continuity of benefits to former contractor workers.  By funding the long-
label: BODY

text: term activities in the Legacy Management program, the Office of Environmental Management is able to
label: BODY

text: concentrate its resources on risk reduction and site closure.

text: Long-Term Surveillance and Maintenance.....................
label: BODY

text: The funding requested for FY 2007 will allow the Office of Legacy Management (LM) to monitor and
label: BODY

text: conduct long-term treatment of 14 sites in accordance with legal, contractual, and regulatory
label: BODY

text: agreements.  Functions include soil, water, and air monitoring, long-term treatment of contaminants,
label: BODY

text: maintenance of contaminant treatment structures, and maintaining security for the sites and other
label: BODY

text: resources associated with the sites.  Activities associated with preparation for transfer of additional
label: BODY

text: sites are also included.
label: BODY

text: The Fernald Site consists of the former Fernald facility.  Responsibility for this site will be
label: BODY

text: transferred at the beginning of FY 2007 from the Office of Environmental Management.  Funding
label: BODY

text: in FY 2007 will allow LM to monitor and conduct long-term surveillance and maintenance
label: BODY

text: activities.
label: BODY

text: The Nevada Offsites consist of eight individual sites, mostly located in the Western States.
label: BODY

text: Responsibility for those sites will be transferred at the beginning of FY 2007 from the Office of
label: BODY

text: Environmental Management.  Funding in FY 2007 will allow LM to monitor and conduct long-
label: BODY

text: term surveillance and maintenance activities at these sites.
label: BODY

text: The funding requested for FY 2007 will allow the LM to monitor and conduct long-term treatment
label: BODY

text: at the Rocky Flats site.  Responsibility for this site will be transferred at the beginning of FY 2007
label: BODY

text: from the Office of Environmental Management.  Functions include soil, water, and air monitoring,
label: BODY

text: and maintaining security for the site and other resources associate with the site.
label: BODY

text: The Office of Legacy Management also manages long-term surveillance and maintenance activities
label: BODY

text: at five other sites and is preparing for transfer of additional sites.  The funding for FY 2007 will
label: BODY

text: allow LM to conduct those activities.
label: BODY

text: Pension and Benefit Continuity........................................
label: BODY

text: At the start of FY 2007, the Office of Legacy Management will receive responsibility for ensuring
label: BODY

text: continuity of pensions and benefits for contractor retirees.  This funding request will include
label: BODY

text: pensions, medical benefits, life insurance, and Medicare Part B payments.
label: BODY

text: This project provides payments to former contractor employees pursuant to administration of DOE
label: BODY

text: liabilities associated with contractor employee retirement benefits.

text: Overview
label: H4

text: FY 2007 Congressional Budget
label: BODY

text: Preface
label: BODY

text: The Office of Nuclear Energy, Science and Technology (NE) leads the Government’s efforts to develop
label: BODY

text: new nuclear energy generation technologies to meet energy and climate goals, to develop advanced,
label: BODY

text: proliferation-resistant nuclear fuel technologies that maximize energy from nuclear fuel, and to maintain
label: BODY

text: and enhance the national nuclear technology infrastructure.  NE serves the present and future energy
label: BODY

text: needs of the Nation by managing the safe operation and maintenance of the DOE critical nuclear
label: BODY

text: infrastructure that provides nuclear technology goods and services.
label: BODY

text: NE has one program completely funded within the Other Defense Activities appropriation - Idaho
label: BODY

text: Sitewide Safeguards and Security.  In FY 2005 and FY 2006, NE has two programs that are partially
label: BODY

text: funded within the Other Defense Activities appropriation - Idaho Facilities Management and Program
label: BODY

text: Direction.  Beginning in FY 2007 funds for these programs are solely requested in the Energy Supply
label: BODY

text: and Conservation appropriation.
label: BODY

text: This Overview will describe Strategic Context, Mission, Benefits, Strategic Goals and Funding by
label: BODY

text: General Goal.  These items together put the appropriation in perspective.  The Annual Performance
label: BODY

text: Results and Targets, Means and Strategies, and Validation and Verification sections address how the
label: BODY

text: goals will be achieved and how performance will be measured.
label: BODY

text: Strategic Context
label: BODY

text: Following publication of the Administration’s “National Energy Policy”, the Department developed a
label: BODY

text: Strategic Plan that defines its mission, four strategic goals for accomplishing that mission, and seven
label: BODY

text: general goals to support the strategic goals.  Each appropriation has developed quantifiable goals to
label: BODY

text: support the general goals.  Thus, the “goal cascade” is the following:
label: BODY

text: Department Mission o Strategic Goal (25 yrs) o General Goal (10-15 yrs) o Program Goal (GPRA
label: BODY

text: Unit) (10-15 yrs)
label: BODY

text: To provide a concrete link between budget, performance, and reporting, the Department developed a
label: BODY

text: “GPRAa unit” concept.  Within DOE, a GPRA unit defines a major activity or group of activities that
label: BODY

text: support the core mission and aligns resources with specific goals.  Each GPRA unit has completed or
label: BODY

text: will complete a Program Assessment Rating Tool (PART).  A unique program goal was developed for
label: BODY

text: each GPRA unit.  A numbering scheme has been established for tracking performance and reporting.b
label: BODY

text: The goal cascade accomplishes two things.  First, it ties major activities for each program to successive
label: BODY

text: goals and, ultimately, to DOE’s mission.  This helps ensure the Department focuses its resources on
label: BODY

text: fulfilling its mission.  Second, the cascade allows DOE to track progress against quantifiable goals and
label: BODY

text: to tie resources to each goal at any level in the cascade.  Thus, the cascade facilitates the integration of
label: BODY

text: budget and performance information in support of the GPRA and the President’s Management Agenda
label: BODY

text: (PMA).
label: BODY

text: a Government Performance and Results Act of 1993
label: BODY

text: b The numbering scheme uses the following numbering convention:  First two digits identify the General Goal (01 through
label: BODY

text: 07); second two digits identify the GPRA Unit; last four digits are reserved for future use.
label: BODY

text: Overview

text: FY 2007 Congressional Budget
label: BODY

text: Mission
label: BODY

text: One of the missions of the Office of Nuclear Energy, Science and Technology is to safeguard DOE
label: BODY

text: nuclear infrastructure that provides nuclear technology goods and services.  NE manages research
label: BODY

text: laboratories and radiological facilities and is the Lead Program Secretarial Officer for the Idaho National
label: BODY

text: Laboratory.
label: BODY

text: Benefits
label: BODY

text: NE plans to safeguard the national nuclear infrastructure currently in place to help meet the Nation’s
label: BODY

text: energy, environmental, health care, and national security needs.  The Idaho Sitewide Safeguards and
label: BODY

text: Security program provides protection of nuclear materials, classified matter, Government property, and
label: BODY

text: other vital assets from unauthorized access, theft, diversion, sabotage, espionage, and other hostile acts
label: BODY

text: that may cause risks to national security, the health and safety of DOE and contractor employees, the
label: BODY

text: public or the environment.
label: BODY

text: Strategic, General, and Program Goals
label: BODY

text: The Department’s Strategic Plan identifies four strategic goals (one each for defense, energy, science,
label: BODY

text: and environmental aspects of the mission) plus seven general goals that tie to the strategic goals.  The
label: BODY

text: Office of Nuclear Energy, Science and Technology supports the following goals:
label: BODY

text: Energy Strategic Goal:  To protect our national and economic security by promoting a diverse supply of
label: BODY

text: reliable, affordable, and environmentally sound energy.
label: BODY

text: General Goal 4, Energy Security:  Improve energy security by developing technologies that foster a
label: BODY

text: diverse supply of reliable, affordable and environmentally sound energy by providing for reliable
label: BODY

text: delivery of energy, guarding against energy emergencies, exploring advanced technologies that make a
label: BODY

text: fundamental improvement in our mix of energy options, and improving energy efficiency.
label: BODY

text: The programs funded by the Office of Nuclear Energy, Science and Technology within Other Defense
label: BODY

text: Activities appropriation have the following Program Goal which contribute to General Goal 4 in the
label: BODY

text: “goal cascade”:
label: BODY

text: Program Goal 04.17.00.00:  Maintain, enhance, and safeguard the Nation’s nuclear infrastructure
label: BODY

text: capability - to meet the Nation’s energy, environmental, medical research, space exploration, and
label: BODY

text: national security needs.
label: BODY

text: Contribution to General Goal 4
label: BODY

text: The Department has the responsibility to maintain and enhance the Nation’s nuclear infrastructure currently in
label: BODY

text: place.  The Idaho Sitewide Safeguards and Security program supports activities that are required to protect the
label: BODY

text: Department’s Idaho complex assets from theft, diversion, sabotage, espionage, unauthorized access,
label: BODY

text: compromise, and other hostile acts which may cause unacceptable adverse impacts on national security,
label: BODY

text: program continuity, the health and safety of employees, the public, or the environment.
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: DBT were accomplished. A DBT Implementation Plan that addresses both the 2003 and the 2004 DBT
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Materials and Fuels Complex has been completed.

text: Idaho National Laboratory
label: BODY

text: Introduction
label: H4

text: The Idaho National Laboratory (INL) is an extensive research and engineering complex that has been
label: BODY

text: the center of nuclear energy research since 1949.  It occupies 890 square miles in southeastern Idaho
label: BODY

text: along the western edge of the Snake River Plain, 42 miles northwest of Idaho Falls, Idaho. There are
label: BODY

text: nine primary facilities at the INL as well as administrative, engineering, and research laboratories in
label: BODY

text: Idaho Falls, Idaho.  The Office of Nuclear Energy, Science and Technology (NE) is the Lead Program
label: BODY

text: Secretarial Office (LPSO) responsible for the Idaho Operations Office (ID). Beginning in the second
label: BODY

text: quarter of FY 2005, ANL-West became part of INL.

text: The Idaho Sitewide Safeguards and Security program provides protection of nuclear materials, classified
label: BODY

text: matter, government property, and other vital assets from unauthorized access, theft, diversion, sabotage,
label: BODY

text: espionage, and other hostile acts that may cause risks to national security, the health and safety of DOE
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Mission
label: BODY

text: The mission of the Infrastructure program within the Other Defense Activities appropriation is to
label: BODY

text: safeguard the national nuclear infrastructure against hostile acts that may cause unacceptable adverse
label: BODY

text: impacts on national security; program continuity; or the health and safety of employees, the public, or
label: BODY

text: the environment.  The mission also includes consolidating nuclear operations required to produce
label: BODY

text: radioisotope power systems at a single, secure site, thereby enhancing the safety and security of these
label: BODY

text: nuclear materials.
label: BODY

text: In FY 2005 and FY 2006, the Idaho Facilities Management program was funded in both the Energy
label: BODY

text: Supply and Conservation and the Other Defense Activities appropriations. Beginning in FY 2007, the
label: BODY

text: Idaho Facilities Management program is requested only under the Energy Supply and Conservation
label: BODY

text: appropriation.  Therefore, the FY 2007 funding tables, performance measures, and budget justification
label: BODY

text: address only the Idaho Sitewide Safeguards and Security program

text: Means and Strategies
label: BODY

text: NE will use various means and strategies to achieve its program goals.  However, various external
label: BODY

text: factors may impact the ability to achieve these goals.  NE also performs collaborative activities to help
label: BODY

text: meet its goals.
label: BODY

text: The Department will implement the following means:
label: BODY

text: Continue planning activities to implement the 2005 Design Basis Threat (DBT) Policy to ensure
label: BODY

text: appropriate protective measures are taken commensurate with risk and consequence.
label: BODY

text: The Department will implement the following strategies:
label: BODY

text: Provide physical protection and maintain operational security systems.  Implement personnel
label: BODY

text: identity verification and diskless workstation systems and conduct semi-annual and annual program
label: BODY

text: reviews.
label: BODY

text: The following external factors could affect NE’s ability to achieve its strategic goal:
label: BODY

text: Idaho Sitewide Safeguards and Security Key External Factors:  Annual review of the Design Basis
label: BODY

text: Threat (DBT) policy, which is based on current intelligence information and threat assessment,
label: BODY

text: could result in significant changes in DBT requirements.  This could affect NE’s ability to achieve
label: BODY

text: goals on schedule.  In addition, significant change in National Security Condition (SECON) level in
label: BODY

text: response to a national security event would require re-prioritization of resources that could impact
label: BODY

text: DBT implementation schedule.  Finally, acquisition and testing of developmental high technology
label: BODY

text: security systems have the potential to reduce the number of protective forces personnel, however,
label: BODY

text: these systems have not been tested in a DOE laboratory environment.
label: BODY

text: Validation and Verification
label: BODY

text: To validate and verify program performance, NE will conduct various internal and external reviews and
label: BODY

text: audits.  NE’s programmatic activities are subject to continuing review by the Congress, the General
label: BODY

text: Accountability Office, the Department’s Inspector General, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, the
label: BODY

text: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, state environmental and health agencies, the Defense Nuclear
label: BODY

text: Facilities Safety Board, and the Department’s Office of Engineering and Construction Management
label: BODY

text: (including DOE Real Property Management Order).  In addition, NE provides continual management
label: BODY

text: and oversight of its vital field infrastructure programs.  Periodic internal and external program reviews
label: BODY

text: evaluate progress against established plans.  These reviews provide an opportunity to verify and validate
label: BODY

text: performance.  Monthly, quarterly, semi-annual and annual reviews, consistent with program
label: BODY

text: management plans, are held to ensure technical progress, cost and schedule adherence, and
label: BODY

text: responsiveness to program requirements.
label: BODY

text: NERAC subcommittees evaluate progress of NE’s research and development programs.  NERAC
label: BODY

text: similarly reviews specific program plans as they are being formulated.  In early FY 2004, NERAC
label: BODY

text: established a Subcommittee on Evaluations. The full NERAC and its subcommittees have provided
label: BODY

text: independent evaluations in the past, but these evaluations never comprehensively covered the entire
label: BODY

text: nuclear energy program.  The new Subcommittee engages appropriate experts to monitor, on a continual
label: BODY

text: basis designated NE programs and evaluate the progress of these programs against (a) direction and
label: BODY

text: guidance provided by the full NERAC and (b) program plans and performance measures developed by
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: the program under evaluation.  This Subcommittee provides arm’s length, independent assessments that
label: BODY

text: are critical to the evaluation of NE programs.

text: Description
label: BODY

text: The Idaho National laboratory (INL) is a multi-program national laboratory that pursues a wide range of
label: BODY

text: nuclear power research and development and other national energy security activities.  The purpose of
label: BODY

text: the Idaho Facilities Management (IFM) Program is to ensure that the infrastructure required to support
label: BODY

text: these efforts is maintained and operated to meet programmatic requirements and in compliance
label: BODY

text: environment, safety and health rules and regulations.
label: BODY

text: The IFM Program manages and operates the three main engineering and research campuses at the INL:
label: BODY

text: (1) the Reactor Technology Center (RTC) at the site, a 890 square mile reservation west of Idaho Falls,
label: BODY

text: (2) the Materials and Fuels Complex (MFC) at the site, and (3) the Science and Technology Complex
label: BODY

text: (STC) in Idaho Falls. As INL landlord, the IFM Program also manages and operates the Central
label: BODY

text: Facilities Area (CFA) at the site and various sitewide infrastructure systems and facilities, such as
label: BODY

text: electrical utility distribution.
label: BODY

text: The STC, CFA and sitewide infrastructure systems and facilities come under Sitewide Infrastructure
label: BODY

text: within the IFM Program.  The funding above is for Sitewide Infrastructure only.  In FY 2005 and FY
label: BODY

text: 2006, the Sitewide Infrastructure part of the IFM program was funded in the Other Defense Activities
label: BODY

text: appropriations.  Beginning in FY 2007, all of the Idaho Facilities Management Program is requested
label: BODY

text: under the Energy Supply and Conservation appropriation.
label: BODY

text: Benefits
label: BODY

text: The IFM program supports “National Energy Policy” goals by maintaining and operating INL basic
label: BODY

text: infrastructure that is required to support facilities dedicated to advanced nuclear energy technology
label: BODY

text: research and many other Federal government activities.  Additional activities include managing special
label: BODY

text: nuclear materials contained in these facilities and the disposition of DOE legacy waste materials under
label: BODY

text: NE ownership.
label: BODY

text: a  Excludes $91,434,000 appropriated under Energy Supply appropriation, a $167,000 rescission and $10,000,000 from Naval
label: BODY

text: Reactors.

label: BODY

text: Reactors.
label: BODY

text: c  Beginning in FY 2007, funding for Idaho Facilities Management is requested under Energy Supply and Conservation
label: BODY

text: appropriation.

text: NE has developed an INL Ten Year Site Plan (TYSP) that establishes the annual budget requirements
label: BODY

text: for the IFM Program, provides a mission needs analysis of facilities and infrastructure, and identifies the
label: BODY

text: maintenance and recapitalization investments needed at the site to support projected missions such as the
label: BODY

text: Advanced Fuel Cycle Initiative, the Generation IV Nuclear Energy Systems Initiative, a range of
label: BODY

text: national security technology programs, and the Idaho Cleanup Project (ICP) under the Office of
label: BODY

text: Environmental Management.  The plan meets the requirements of DOE Order 430.1B, Real Property
label: BODY

text: Asset Management (RPAM).

label: BODY

text: Sitewide Infrastructure Base Operations maintains the STC, the CFA, and the INL common-use
label: BODY

text: facilities, utilities, equipment, and land.  The CFA consists of 72 buildings and 60 major support
label: BODY

text: structures.  The STC includes 30 DOE owned and leased buildings consisting of office space and
label: BODY

text: extensive laboratory facilities.  The Sitewide Infrastructure outside NE campuses and the ICP
label: BODY

text: work complexes consists of 34 buildings and 35 major utility systems and structures.
label: BODY

text: Routine Maintenance and Repair................................
label: BODY

text: The goal of this program is to fund routine maintenance and repair within the target industry
label: BODY

text: range of 2% to 4% of Replacement Plant Value (RPV).  The use of this industry benchmark was
label: BODY

text: recommended by the National Research Council’s Congressionally-sponsored 1998 study,
label: BODY

text: Stewardship of Federal Facilities.
label: BODY

text: In FY 2005 and FY 2006, GPPs for Sitewide Infrastructure support recapitalization of the INL in
label: BODY

text: accordance with DOE Order 430.1B, Real Property Asset Management and the INL TYSP.
label: BODY

text: In FY 2005 and FY 2006, equipment purchases for Sitewide Infrastructure include such things as
label: BODY

text: shop and miscellaneous maintenance equipment, vehicles and heavy equipment, and laboratory
label: BODY

text: equipment. This funding primarily provides replacements for aged, deteriorated equipment and
label: BODY

text: procurement of new equipment to meet emerging requirements.

text: Description
label: BODY

text: The mission of the Idaho Sitewide Safeguards and Security (S&S) program is to protect DOE interests
label: BODY

text: from theft, diversion, sabotage, espionage, unauthorized access, compromise, and other hostile acts that
label: BODY

text: may cause unacceptable adverse impacts on national security; program continuity; or the health and
label: BODY

text: safety of employees, the public, or the environment.
label: BODY

text: a Program levels reflect Work for Others (WFO) before the bottom line reduction to the NE appropriation for a “Security
label: BODY

text: Charge for Reimbursable Work.” This offset is displayed above by fiscal year.  The new budget authority, as well as the
label: BODY

text: offsetting collections (such as when other agencies are using the facility), for the WFO portion of the S&S budget is included
label: BODY

text: in Departmental Administration’s Cost of Work for Others program, which is managed by the Department’s Office of Chief
label: BODY

text: Financial Officer.
label: BODY

text: Page 137

label: BODY

text: Idaho Sitewide Safeguards and Security
label: BODY

text: FY 2007 Congressional Budget
label: BODY

text: Benefits
label: BODY

text: This program is designed to support DOE’s Defense Strategic Goal to protect our national security.  The
label: BODY

text: Idaho Sitewide Safeguards and Security program provides protection of nuclear materials, classified
label: BODY

text: matter, Government property, and other vital assets from unauthorized access, theft, diversion, sabotage,
label: BODY

text: espionage, and other hostile acts that may cause risks to national security, the health and safety of DOE
label: BODY

text: and contractor employees, the public or the environment.
label: BODY

text: DOE will fully implement the 2003 Design Basis Threat (DBT) in FY 2006 by completing physical
label: BODY

text: upgrades and reducing Category I facilities at INL to two co-located Category I facilities protected by a
label: BODY

text: single Perimeter Intrusion Detection and Assessment System (PIDAS).  Implementation is in accordance
label: BODY

text: with the approved resource-loaded Idaho Site DBT Implementation Plan.
label: BODY

text: DOE will continue planning activities toward implementation of the 2005 DBT policy requirements
label: BODY

text: using a risk-informed approach to physical upgrades.  Both the 2004 and 2005 DBT policy requirements
label: BODY

text: increased the strength of the postulated adversarial threat over the 2003 DBT; although detailed
label: BODY

text: vulnerability assessments have not yet been completed, significant security system physical upgrades are
label: BODY

text: expected.  DOE’s Office of Independent Oversight and Performance Assurance conducted a site
label: BODY

text: assistance visit at Idaho to identify opportunities to increase security in a more cost effective manner
label: BODY

text: through better integration of highly advanced security technology with site security operations.  Pending
label: BODY

text: the completion of vulnerability assessments, which will guide protection strategy, DOE believes that
label: BODY

text: early investment in improved positions for defending forces, more capable detection systems, and
label: BODY

text: technological deterrent devices at target locations will result in cost avoidance over the lifetime by
label: BODY

text: relying more on technology and tactics than additional protective force members to counter the revised
label: BODY

text: threat.
label: BODY

text: DOE will also implement Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS) 201, entitled Personal
label: BODY

text: Identity Verification of Federal Employees and Contractors. FIPS 201 was developed to satisfy the
label: BODY

text: requirements of Homeland Security Presidential Directive/HSPD-12. The new standard requires
label: BODY

text: improving identity and authentication of Federal employees and contractors accessing Federal facilities
label: BODY

text: and information systems.
label: BODY

text: DOE would like to begin the transition to a diskless classified computing environment in FY 2007.  This
label: BODY

text: initiative would be funded by user programs.
label: BODY

text: Detailed Justification
label: BODY

text: (dollars in thousands)
label: BODY

text: Physical Protection Protective Forces provides for security guards or other specialized
label: BODY

text: personnel and equipment, training, and management needed to effectively carry out the
label: BODY

text: protection tasks during normal and security emergency conditions.
label: BODY

text: Physical Security Protection Systems provides for equipment to protect vital security interests
label: BODY

text: and Government property per the local threat, including performance testing, intrusion detection
label: BODY

text: and assessment, fences, barriers, secure storage, lighting, sensors, entry/access control devices,
label: BODY

text: locks, explosives detection, and vital components and tamper-safe monitoring.
label: BODY

text: In FY 2006, NE will initiate a Technology Deployment R&D activity with the Office of
label: BODY

text: Security and Safety Performance Assurance to test new security technologies for eventual
label: BODY

text: deployment in the DOE complex to meet the DBT policy requirements.
label: BODY

text: In FY 2007, NE will:
label: BODY

text: maintain operational physical security systems to include barriers, lighting, sensors, etc.
label: BODY

text: implement Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS 201) by installing card readers
label: BODY

text: that will incorporate the new technology for access compatibility with the new badging
label: BODY

text: technology.
label: BODY

text: -    continue planning activities associated with implementation of the 2005 DBT initiated in
label: BODY

text: FY 2006 at the Idaho site.  Specific activities include design and initiate installation of
label: BODY

text: security protection systems to include barriers, lighting, and sensors.
label: BODY

text: Transportation provides for all security-related transportation for intra-site transfers of special
label: BODY

text: nuclear materials (including safe havens), weapons, and other classified material that is not
label: BODY

text: funded through the National Nuclear Security Administration’s Office of Transportation
label: BODY

text: Safeguards (OTS).  The safeguards and security program pays for cost of protection and secure
label: BODY

text: movement. Transportation activities are included in Material Control and Accountability
label: BODY

text: (MC&A) beginning in FY 2006.
label: BODY

text: Information Security ensures that classified and sensitive unclassified matter is adequately
label: BODY

text: protected, including export controls, classified matter protection and control, technical
label: BODY

text: surveillance countermeasures, and operations security.
label: BODY

text: Personnel Security includes clearance program, adjudication, security awareness and education,
label: BODY

text: visit control, Personnel Security Assurance Program, psychological/medical assessments, and
label: BODY

text: administrative review costs.  Security Investigations (SI) activities performed by the Federal
label: BODY

text: Bureau of Investigation (FBI) and the Office of Personnel Management (OPM)-associated
label: BODY

text: access authorizations are funded by the Office of Security and are not requested/displayed in
label: BODY

text: NE’s budget.
label: BODY

text: In FY 2007, NE will:
label: BODY

text: maintain the Human Reliability Program

text: Material Control and Accountability...........................
label: BODY

text: Material Control and Accountability (MC&A) provides for the protection of special nuclear
label: BODY

text: materials (SNM), nuclear weapons, test devices, and weapons components and parts by
label: BODY

text: determining and documenting the amounts of nuclear materials in packaged items.  The cost of
label: BODY

text: activities such as MC&A training, proper measurement of materials, and performing a physical
label: BODY

text: inventory are included in the budgets of those programs responsible for processing or storing
label: BODY

text: SNM and nuclear weapons components and parts, and are not included here.
label: BODY

text: Program Management includes policy oversight and development and updating of security
label: BODY

text: plans, assessments, and approvals to determine if assets are at risk.  Also included are contractor
label: BODY

text: management and administration, planning, and integration of security activities into facility
label: BODY

text: operations.
label: BODY

text: Cyber Security ensures that sensitive and classified information that is electronically processed,
label: BODY

text: transmitted, or stored is properly identified and protected.  The Cyber Security activity ensures
label: BODY

text: that electronic systems are appropriately marked and protected; automated information and
label: BODY

text: protection systems are tested; Communications Security (COMSEC) and Telecommunications
label: BODY

text: Electronics Material Protected from Emanating Spurious Transmissions (TEMPEST) measures
label: BODY

text: are in place; and an appropriate level of infrastructure reliability and integrity is maintained.
label: BODY

text: In FY 2007, NE will:
label: BODY

text: implement the Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS 201).  Specific activities
label: BODY

text: include card readers and biometric readers to be attached to each unclassified computer
label: BODY

text: system and special hardware for around 2,000 registered remote access users.
label: BODY

text: NE will also implement hardware and software for a new system to implement
label: BODY

text: Certification Authority Capability.

text: Mission
label: BODY

text: Program Direction provides the Federal staffing resources and associated costs required to provide
label: BODY

text: overall direction and execution of the Office of Nuclear Energy, Science and Technology (NE).  NE
label: BODY

text: promotes secure, competitive, and environmentally responsible nuclear technologies to serve the present
label: BODY

text: and future energy needs of the country.  NE carries out this mission in several ways.  As the central
label: BODY

text: organization with the Federal Government’s core expertise in nuclear technology, NE directs the
label: BODY

text: Nation’s investment in nuclear science and technology by sponsoring research at the national
label: BODY

text: laboratories, U.S. universities, and private industry.  Through its support of innovative, higher risk
label: BODY

text: science and by helping to preserve the national research and development infrastructure, NE works to
label: BODY

text: advance the responsible use of nuclear technology.  NE also manages the safe operation and
label: BODY

text: maintenance of critical nuclear infrastructure and provides nuclear technology goods and services to
label: BODY

text: industry and government.
label: BODY

text: NE is the Lead Program Secretarial Officer (LPSO) of the Idaho site.  NE Headquarters and the Idaho
label: BODY

text: Operations Office reorganized in January 2005 to more effectively support the new nuclear energy
label: BODY

text: missions and prepare for the oversight and management of the new contracts for the operation of the
label: BODY

text: Idaho site.  This new structure will carry out all programmatic, project, and landlord responsibilities
label: BODY

text: assigned to NE now and in the future, both as LPSO and Contracting Officer for DOE’s operations in
label: BODY

text: Idaho, and as responsible PSO for programs, projects, facilities, and operations at other DOE sites.  In
label: BODY

text: a  Beginning in FY 2007, funding for Idaho Operations Office is requested under Energy Supply and Conservation.
label: BODY

text: b This number represents actual FY 2005 FTE usage.

label: BODY

text: As stated in the Departmental Strategic Plan, DOE’s Strategic and General Goals will be accomplished
label: BODY

text: not only through the efforts of the major program offices in the Department but with additional effort
label: BODY

text: from offices which support the programs in carrying out the mission.  The Office of Nuclear Energy,
label: BODY

text: Science and Technology performs critical functions which directly support the mission of the
label: BODY

text: Department.  These functions include: maintain, enhance, and safeguard the Nation’s nuclear
label: BODY

text: infrastructure capability - to meet the Nation’s energy, environmental, medical research, space
label: BODY

text: exploration, and national security needs.

text: Description
label: BODY

text: From FY 1999 through 2006, funding has been provided within the Other Defense Activities
label: BODY

text: appropriation to offset funding within the Departmental Administration appropriation.  This offset
label: BODY

text: addresses the significant amount of administrative support activities performed within the Departmental
label: BODY

text: Administration appropriation that are of direct benefit to the Department’s defense related programs.
label: BODY

text: Per direction provided in the FY 2004 Energy Water and Development conference report, the FY 2007
label: BODY

text: budget request reflects a proportional contribution from Other Defense Activities for Departmental
label: BODY

text: Administration costs.  This budget offsets Departmental Administration administrative work that
label: BODY

text: Preface
label: BODY

text: The Department of Energy operates and supervises a great number of programs to further its National
label: BODY

text: Defense and the Environmental Strategic Goals.  Many of these programs seek to balance the interests
label: BODY

text: of different and sometimes competing stakeholders. The Office of Hearings and Appeals (OHA)
label: BODY

text: provides legal adjudicatory services for the Department’s programs so that these conflicting interests
label: BODY

text: may be decided in a fair, impartial and efficient manner.
label: BODY

text: Within the Other Defense Activities Appropriation, OHA operates with three principal legal staffs – the
label: BODY

text: Office of Legal Analysis, the Office of Financial Analysis and the Office of Economic Analysis.
label: BODY

text: This Overview will describe Strategic Context, Mission, and Benefits. These items together put this
label: BODY

text: Appropriation in perspective.
label: BODY

text: Strategic Context
label: BODY

text: Following publication of the Administration’s National Energy Policy, the Department developed a
label: BODY

text: Strategic Plan that defines the mission, four strategic goals for accomplishing that mission, and seven
label: BODY

text: general goals to support the strategic goals. As stated in the Departmental Strategic Plan, DOE’s
label: BODY

text: Strategic and General Goals will be accomplished not only through the efforts of the major program
label: BODY

text: offices in the Department but with additional effort from offices which support the programs in carrying
label: BODY

text: out the mission. OHA performs critical functions which directly support the mission of the Department.
label: BODY

text: These functions include ensuring, through its role in conducting hearings in Personnel Security cases,
label: BODY

text: that only trustworthy employees are allowed access to classified information or controlled nuclear
label: BODY

text: materials.  Likewise, in its supervision of Whistleblower hearings, OHA insures that the Department has
label: BODY

text: a workplace where employee concerns about health and safety, fraud, waste, abuse or mismanagement
label: BODY

text: may be freely expressed to DOE or contractor management without fear of retaliation.   OHA’s role in
label: BODY

text: deciding Appeals and Applications for Exceptions supports the Department in ensuring that relevant
label: BODY

text: regulations and statutes are applied properly and without undue disruption to the private sector. This
label: BODY

text: directly benefits the public and reduces the Department’s litigation costs in Federal courts.
label: BODY

text: a  Reflects a 1% rescission in accordance with P.L. 109-148, Department of Defense Appropriations Act, 2006.
label: BODY

text: Mission
label: BODY

text: OHA’s mission is to conduct fair and efficient hearings and to issue decisions of the Department with
label: BODY

text: respect to any adjudicative proceedings that the Secretary may delegate.  OHA’s jurisdiction includes,
label: BODY

text: for example, security clearance hearings, hearings of complaints filed under the DOE Contractor
label: BODY

text: Employee Protection Program as well as appeals requesting review of any determination reached by any
label: BODY

text: official within the Department under OHA’s jurisdiction.
label: BODY

text: As stated in the Departmental Strategic Plan, DOE’s Strategic and General Goals will be accomplished
label: BODY

text: not only through the efforts of the major program offices in the Department but with additional effort
label: BODY

text: from offices which support the programs in carrying out the mission of the Department. OHA performs
label: BODY

text: critical functions which directly support the mission. These functions include ensuring, through its role
label: BODY

text: in conducting hearings in Personnel Security cases, that only trustworthy employees are allowed access
label: BODY

text: to classified information or controlled nuclear materials.  Likewise, in its supervision of Whistleblower
label: BODY

text: hearings, OHA insures that the Department has a workplace where employee concerns about health and
label: BODY

text: safety, fraud, waste, abuse or mismanagement may be freely expressed to DOE or contractor
label: BODY

text: management without fear of retaliation. OHA’s role in deciding Appeals and Applications for
label: BODY

text: Exceptions supports the Department in ensuring that relevant regulations and statutes are applied
label: BODY

text: properly and without undue disruption to the private sector. This directly benefits the public and reduces
label: BODY

text: the Department’s litigation costs in Federal courts.
label: BODY

text: Benefits
label: BODY

text: In its adjudicatory mission for the Department, OHA offers a fair, impartial and customer-friendly
label: BODY

text: process in which firms and individuals may seek review of agency actions. OHA is also charged with
label: BODY

text: conducting hearings in Personnel Security cases.  OHA issues timely, high quality decisions in cases
label: BODY

text: involving DOE personnel security clearance adjudications that ensure only trustworthy personnel are
label: BODY

text: allowed access to classified information and special nuclear materials. Thus, OHA directly supports the
label: BODY

text: Department’s Defense Strategic Goal of helping ensure the security of the nuclear weapons stockpile.
label: BODY

text: OHA also conducts investigations and hearings concerning whistleblower complaints filed by DOE
label: BODY

text: contractor employees and for issuing final agency decisions resolving them.  In these cases, OHA strives
label: BODY

text: to balance the public interest in promoting a workplace where concerns may be freely expressed without
label: BODY

text: retaliation against the need of DOE contractors to manage their resources efficiently. This is especially
label: BODY

text: important with regard to the Department’s Environmental Strategic Goal to ensure that cleanup of the
label: BODY

text: environmental legacy of the Cold War is effectively performed.
label: BODY

text: OHA also analyzes and decides appeals requesting review of any determination reached by any other
label: BODY

text: official within the Department under the jurisdiction of the Secretary, including initial determinations
label: BODY

text: under the Freedom of Information Act, the Privacy Act, the payments-equal-to-taxes (PETT) provisions
label: BODY

text: of the Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982, the special assessment provisions for the Uranium Enrichment
label: BODY

text: Decontamination and Decommissioning Fund under the Energy Policy Act of 1992, and the
label: BODY

text: reimbursement of costs of remedial actions at active uranium or thorium processing sites under the
label: BODY

text: Energy Policy Act of 1992.  OHA is responsible for deciding Applications for Exception from the
label: BODY

text: generally applicable requirements of a rule, regulation or order of the Department.  The Office also
label: BODY

text: analyzes Petitions for Special Redress seeking "extraordinary relief" apart from or in addition to any
label: BODY

text: other remedy provided in the Department's enabling statutes. By ensuring that the Department properly
label: BODY

text: applies relevant regulations and statutes to affected parties, OHA directly benefits the public and saves
label: BODY

text: the Department litigation expenses in federal courts.
label: BODY

text: Safeguards and Security

text: Program Mission
label: BODY

text: The mission of the Safeguards and Security (S&S) program at each Department of Energy (DOE) site is
label: BODY

text: to protect DOE interests from theft, diversion, sabotage, espionage, unauthorized access, compromise,
label: BODY

text: and other hostile acts which may cause unacceptable adverse impacts on national security, program
label: BODY

text: continuity, the health and safety of employees, the public or the environment.
label: BODY

text: This section of the budget provides summary budget estimates of the Department’s S&S programs.
label: BODY

text: Details of the individual S&S programs and their budgets are found in the following program budget
label: BODY

text: justifications:
label: BODY

text: National Nuclear Security Administration
label: BODY

text: Environmental Management
label: BODY

text: Security and Safety Performance Assurance
label: BODY

text: Information Management
label: BODY

text: Science
label: BODY

text: Nuclear Energy
label: BODY

text: Program Overview
label: H4

text: The budget for the Department’s direct funded S&S programs is organized to ensure consistency in
label: BODY

text: program and budget execution and ensure adequate management, direction, tracking and monitoring of
label: BODY

text: security costs throughout the Department.  Each S&S program budget provides high visibility for S&S
label: BODY

text: issues and helps the Department prioritize functions for effective and efficient S&S program
label: BODY

text: implementation.  Furthermore, the structure of the S&S budgets ensures consistency in budget execution
label: BODY

text: across diverse programs, principally the National Nuclear Security Administration, Environmental
label: BODY

text: Management, Science, and Nuclear Energy.  For these Field Security programs, the budget structure
label: BODY

text: takes the form of the following seven program elements:
label: BODY

text: 1.  Protective Forces: Provides for the protection of special nuclear materials, information, employees,
label: H4

text: and government property from theft, diversion, sabotage, and malicious destruction.
label: BODY

text: 2.  Security Systems:  Addresses access control and interior/exterior intrusion detection systems.
label: H4

text: 3.  Information Security:  Ensures that individuals protect classified matter and sensitive unclassified
label: H4

text: matter, and establishes protection systems that require degrees of protection for each classification level.
label: BODY

text: 4.  Cyber Security:  Assures effective and efficient protection of computer and technical resources.
label: H4

text: 5.  Personnel Security: Supports activities associated with the access authorization program.
label: H4

text: Page 159
label: BODY

text: Other Defense Activities/Security
label: BODY

text: Safeguards and Security Crosscut
label: BODY

text: FY 2007 Congressional Budget
label: BODY

text: 6.  Material Control and Accountability:  Provides assurance that the nuclear materials used and/or
label: H4

text: stored at DOE facilities are properly controlled and accounted for at all times.
label: BODY

text: 7.  Program Management: Assures a framework for efficient and effective security operations.
label: H4

label: BODY

text: The composition of the S&S crosscut is modified as security-related DOE organizations are changed to
label: BODY

text: more effectively address the security concerns that confront the Department.

text: Protective Forces
label: BODY

text: Mission
label: BODY

text: The mission of Protective Forces is to protect the Department’s critical assets which include nuclear
label: BODY

text: weapons in DOE custody, nuclear weapons components, special nuclear materials, classified
label: BODY

text: information and DOE facilities against a spectrum of threats, including terrorist activity, sabotage,
label: BODY

text: espionage, theft, diversion, loss or unauthorized use.  To accomplish this mission:
label: BODY

text: Protective Force programs throughout the complex provide for salaries, wages and benefits for
label: BODY

text: personnel; proper management and supervision; and sufficient quantities of well maintained and
label: BODY

text: logically deployed equipment and facilities to ensure effective performance of assigned functions
label: BODY

text: and tasks under normal and emergency conditions.
label: BODY

text: Protective Forces programs perform critical functions including the conduct of access control and
label: BODY

text: security response operations; the physical protection of special nuclear material, classified matter
label: BODY

text: and information, and government property; emergency response forces and tactical assistance during
label: BODY

text: events as well as an on-scene security commander; random patrols; coordination with local law
label: BODY

text: enforcement and protective force elements aimed at providing effective response to emergency
label: BODY

text: situations; random prohibited article inspections; security alarm monitoring and dispatch services;
label: BODY

text: the collection and destruction of classified matter; and constant testing of the protective force to
label: BODY

text: respond to various event scenarios.
label: BODY

text: Protective Forces Programs maintain a Special Response Team capability to provide resolution of
label: BODY

text: incidents that require effective and timely response with force options that exceed the capability of
label: BODY

text: front line protective force personnel.  This includes recapture and recovery operations involving the
label: BODY

text: use of special weapons, systems and tactics to effect recovery of special nuclear material under
label: BODY

text: authorized control.
label: BODY

text: The mission of Security Systems is the physical protection of special nuclear material and vital
label: BODY

text: equipment, sensitive information, Departmental property and unclassified facilities.  Included are
label: BODY

text: buildings, fences, barriers, lighting, sensors, surveillance devices, entry control devices, access control
label: BODY

text: systems, explosive detection systems, power systems and other real property and hardware designed for,
label: BODY

text: or affecting security.  This hardware and equipment is operated and used to support the protection of
label: BODY

text: DOE property and other interests of national security.
label: BODY

text: Security Systems programs support DOE-wide efforts required to conduct performance assurance
label: BODY

text: testing.  These programs also ensure that security alarm systems are operational and functioning in
label: BODY

text: accordance with applicable DOE Orders.  Security System programs are also responsible for two
label: BODY

text: essential subprograms:  (1) a barriers/secure storage/lock program to restrict, limit, delay or deny entry
label: BODY

text: into a designated area; and (2), an entry control/access program that provides positive identification of
label: BODY

text: personnel requiring access to facilities and initial access to facilities in general, ensuring that persons
label: BODY

text: entering/leaving facilities are authorized, and do not introduce prohibited articles into or remove
label: BODY

text: Government property from Departmental facilities.
label: BODY

text: Estimates are provided for all access control administrative activity involving production, accountability
label: BODY

text: and destruction of access authorization badges and firearms credentials.  Estimates are also provided for
label: BODY

text: vital systems components and tamper-safe oversight is provided by monitoring and responding to
label: BODY

text: alarms, determining access and securing all alarmed structures on site.  In addition, this element
label: BODY

text: provides for handling all radio communications for the protection of the facilities.
label: BODY

text: Information Security
label: BODY

text: Mission
label: BODY

text: The mission of Information Security is to ensure that material and documents that may contain sensitive
label: BODY

text: and classified information are accurately and consistently identified, properly reviewed for content,
label: BODY

text: appropriately marked and protected from unauthorized disclosure, and ultimately destroyed in an
label: BODY

text: approved manner.
label: BODY

text: Information Security programs provides for plans, policies, procedures and training to ensure that all
label: BODY

text: employees are aware of the requirements for the identification, review, classification, declassification,
label: BODY

text: marking, protection and proper disposal of sensitive information and classified material.  In addition,
label: BODY

text: operational security considerations are used to preclude inadvertent compromise.
label: BODY

text: Cyber Security
label: BODY

text: Mission
label: BODY

text: The mission of Cyber Security is to ensure that sensitive and classified information that is electronically
label: BODY

text: processed, transmitted, or stored, is properly identified and protected.  Cyber Security programs also
label: BODY

text: ensure that electronic systems are appropriately marked and protected.  The programs plan, document,
label: BODY

text: and test classified automated information systems (AIS), communications security (COMSEC),
label: BODY

text: TEMPEST; and maintain an appropriate level of infrastructure reliability and integrity, as well as an
label: BODY

text: unclassified AIS program.  Included are appropriate plans, policies and procedures, assessments, tests,
label: BODY

text: monitoring and self-assessments, certifications, and user and administrator training/awareness.
label: BODY

text: Personnel Security
label: BODY

text: Mission
label: BODY

text: The mission of Personnel Security is to support the access authorization program (excluding Security
label: BODY

text: Investigations), and ensure security sensitivity through security briefings such as the initial refresher and
label: BODY

text: termination briefings, re-orientations, computer based training, special workshops and classes,
label: BODY

text: publications, closed circuit television programs, signs, posters and special event days.  Support for the
label: BODY

text: access authorization program includes: (1) personnel security assurance program, adjudications,
label: BODY

text: screening and analysis of personnel security cases for determining eligibility for access authorizations,
label: BODY

text: administrative reviews, and handling of Freedom of Information and Privacy Act requests related to
label: BODY

text: security access authorizations; (2) security awareness and education; and (3) operating and maintenance
label: BODY

text: estimates associated with classified/unclassified visits and assignments by foreign nationals.
label: BODY

text: Material Control and Accountability
label: BODY

text: Mission
label: BODY

text: The mission of Material Control and Accountability (MC&A) is to provide assurance that nuclear
label: BODY

text: materials are properly controlled and accounted for at all times.  MC&A provides evidence that all
label: BODY

text: nuclear materials are accounted for appropriately and that theft, diversion, or operational loss has not
label: BODY

text: occurred.  MC&A also supports weapons production, nuclear nonproliferation, nuclear materials
label: BODY

text: operations, facility closure, and nuclear critical safety by determining and documenting the amounts of
label: BODY

text: nuclear materials in weapons and packaged items.  MC&A administration includes the following: (1)
label: BODY

text: assessing the levels of protection, control and accounting required for the types and quantities of
label: BODY

text: materials at each facility; (2) documenting facility plans for nuclear materials control and accounting;
label: BODY

text: (3) assigning authorities and responsibilities for MC&A functions; (4) ensuring that facility MC&A
label: BODY

text: personnel are trained and qualified to perform their responsibilities; (5) establishing programs to report
label: BODY

text: occurrences such as nuclear material theft, the loss of control or inability to account for nuclear
label: BODY

text: materials, or evidence of malevolent acts; (6) conducting performance testing of required program
label: BODY

text: elements; and (7) establishing facility programs to conduct and document internal assessments of their
label: BODY

text: operations and MC&A programs.
label: BODY

text: Program Management
label: BODY

text: Mission
label: BODY

text: The mission of Program Management is to develop a framework for efficient and effective security
label: BODY

text: operations.  This includes the development and updating of S&S plans, conducting vulnerability
label: BODY

text: assessments to determine if assets are at risk, modeling to ensure the plans and operations meet mission
label: BODY

text: objectives, identifying assets that need protection, developing local threat assessments and participating
label: BODY

text: in the S&S quality panel process and security education.  In addition, these programs ensure that plans
label: BODY

text: are developed and revised in accordance with DOE Orders, professional and technical training is
label: BODY

text: administered, and goals and objectives of the Office of Security and Safety Performance Assurance are
label: BODY

text: implemented complex wide.
label: BODY

text: The programs develop S&S plans or other applicable security plans and implement S&S requirements,
label: BODY

text: conduct surveys to determine whether S&S requirements have been implemented, respond to national
label: BODY

text: and local threats and perform a vulnerability analysis that measures the risk of S&S assets.  Program
label: BODY

text: Management includes participation in the quality panel process which raises issues from the field to the
label: BODY

text: headquarters managers and ensures that the staff is properly educated with respect to security matters.
label: BODY
